column2: 181.575 Specific Information Not to be Collected or Maintained
131.675 Dispersal of Unlawful or Riotous Assemblies

column1: • DIR 700.00, National Incident Management System (NIMS) and Incident Command System (ICS)

column2: A non-violent form of protest or resistance to obeying certain laws, demands or commands of a government.&nbsp

An unlawful assembly that constitutes a clear and present danger of riot, disorder, interference with traffic upon the public streets or when another immediate threat to public safety, peace or order appears. &nbsp
Law enforcement response to a pre-planned or spontaneous event, activity, or occurrence that has become a civil disturbance and may require dispersal of the crowd and/or arrests.&nbsp
Encompasses law enforcement management, intervention, and control strategies when responding to all forms of public assemblies and gatherings. &nbsp
column3: Also refers specifically to strategies and tactics employed before, during, and after a gathering for the purpose of maintaining the event&rsquo
column5: These could include event planning, pre-event contact with group leaders, information gathering, and other means.&nbsp

column2: For the purposes of this Directive, a command member who has received special training in crowd management/crowd control.&nbsp
column4: The Chief of Police will designate a command staff member to serve as the CMIC for every major demonstration and/or special event. &nbsp
column5: This position possesses the overall responsibility for managing the demonstration by establishing objectives, planning strategies, and implementing tactics in accordance with this Directive and Directive 700.00, National Incident Management System (NIMS) and Incident Command System (ICS). &nbsp
column6: This position reports to the Assistant Chief of Operations during demonstrations. &nbsp

column2: A lawful assembly of persons who have organized primarily to exercise their First Amendment right to express political or social doctrine views and attract public attention. &nbsp
column3: Planned or spontaneous demonstrations include, but are not limited to, the distribution of literature, displaying of banners, vigils, rallies, marches, strikes or other similar activity (e.g., event, concert, festival, street theater, etc.). &nbsp
column4: Lawful demonstrations can become civil disturbances.&nbsp

column2: The right to speak, associate, assemble, and petition the government
column3: speech that is protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution and Article I, sections 8 and 26 of the Oregon Constitution.&nbsp
column4: For the purposes of this Directive, the rights issuing from both the federal and state Constitutions are collectively referred to as First Amendment rights.&nbsp

column2: A proposal that provides a concise and consistent means of capturing and communicating overall incident priorities, objectives and strategies for both operational and support activities.&nbsp
The individual responsible for all incident activities, including the development of strategies and tactics and the ordering and release of resources.&nbsp
column3: The IC has the overall authority and responsibility for conducting incident operations and is responsible for the management of all incident operations at the incident site. &nbsp

column1: <li>Mobile Field Force (MFF): Sworn members, who are trained in basic crowd control tactics and techniques, organized into a squad and deployed to assist in the management of a crowd.&nbsp

column2: A member, designated by the CMIC, who develops and implements strategy and tactics to carry out incident objectives.&nbsp
column3: The designated member organizes, assigns, and supervises the tactical response resources.&nbsp
s non-cooperation with a member that does not involve violence or other active conduct by the individual.&nbsp

column2: The person(s) designated by a demonstration organizer or permit holder to act on behalf of, and with the authority of, the demonstration organizer or permit holder.&nbsp
A Bureau member who has been designated by the IC as the primary contact for communication with the demonstration's Person-In-Charge to police. &nbsp

column3: s all-hazard team of members who are specially trained to assist in the response to manmade/natural disasters and other emergency management situations which include, but are not limited to, the management and control of crowds through various tactics and techniques.&nbsp

column1: <li>Riot: Six or more persons engaging in tumultuous and violent conduct and thereby intentionally or recklessly creating a grave risk of causing public alarm, excluding persons who are engaged in passive resistance.&nbsp

column2: Generally, a non-routine activity within a community that brings together a large number of people.&nbsp

column1: <li>Squad: A group of members tasked with accomplishing certain goals and missions.&nbsp
column2: A minimum of one sergeant shall be assigned to each squad.&nbsp
column3: The maximum span of control is twelve members per sergeant. (ICS refers to this group as a &ldquo

column1: • The purpose of this Directive is to provide guidance for demonstrations, special events, the managing of crowds during demonstrations, and controlling crowds during civil disturbances.
<li>Freedom of speech, association, assembly, and the right to petition the government are subject to reasonable restrictions on the time, place, and manner of expression
column2: the content of the speech does not provide the basis for imposing limitations on First Amendment rights.

column1: <li>The Portland Police Bureau recognizes that the City of Portland has a tradition of free speech and assembly. &nbsp
column2: It is the responsibility and priority of the Portland Police Bureau not to unduly impede the exercise of First Amendment rights and to provide for the safe and lawful expression of speech, while also maintaining the public safety, peace and order. &nbsp
column3: A police response that impedes otherwise protected speech must be narrowly tailored to serve a significant government interest.&nbsp

column1: • While the First Amendment provides broad protections for the expression of speech, it does not provide protection for criminal acts including, but not limited to, riot, disorder, interference with traffic upon the public streets, or other immediate threats to public safety, peace or order.
<li>The Bureau recognizes that demonstrations and events are dynamic in nature.&nbsp
column2: Accordingly, members will monitor the crowd throughout the event to assess the level of risk posed to both demonstrators and the public at large, with the goal of minimizing potential violence, injury or damage to property.&nbsp
column3: Member response should be commensurate to overall crowd behavior, and members should differentiate between groups or individuals who are engaging in criminal behavior or otherwise posing a threat to the safety of others and those in the crowd who are lawfully demonstrating.&nbsp
column4: Members will strive to maintain a diplomatic presence to dissuade participants from engaging in civil disturbance and to encourage crowd self-monitoring.

column1: <li>If a demonstration becomes a civil disturbance, the Bureau has a responsibility to reasonably protect public safety and restore peace and order.&nbsp
column2: The preferred police response is one of crowd management rather than crowd control.&nbsp
column3: The Bureau should employ only objectively reasonable crowd management and/or crowd control tactics with the intent to de-escalate the situation.&nbsp
column4: If there is an escalation to a civil disturbance that is no longer isolated to individuals or small groups, members shall adjust their tactical response to adequately resolve the incident in an attempt to restore safety, peace and order.

column1: <li>All members are expected to conduct themselves in a professional manner when interacting with persons involved with demonstrations and special events. &nbsp
column2: Members shall identify themselves by wearing a visible name badge or identification number at all times. &nbsp
column4: s communication with members of the crowd will remain content neutral.&nbsp

column1: 1. Directive 1010.00, Use of Force, governs all uses of force, including in crowd management and crowd control situations.
2. The Bureau shall use the national, standardized and exhaustive system established in the Incident Command System (ICS) to plan and manage significant incidents and events.
column2: Members shall refer to Directive 700.00, National Incident Management System (NIMS) and Incident Command System (ICS), for specific guidance regarding incident management.
>2.1. When time and circumstances permit and a police response is reasonably anticipated, the IC shall develop an Incident Action Plan (IAP) prior to the start of an incident or event.

column3: s goals are to facilitate participants&rsquo
column4: lawful objectives and protect their right to assemble.&nbsp
column5: Furthermore, where event participants comply with City laws and ordinances, the Bureau shall encourage and support participants&rsquo
column6: efforts to monitor themselves in an attempt to limit member involvement.

column2: >3.1.1. When a police response is requested or deemed necessary by the Bureau:

>3.1.1.1. The Bureau shall make reasonable efforts to contact and engage in dialogue with known event or demonstration organizers to assist the Bureau in its planning and to develop a shared understanding of the organizers&rsquo
column4: Similarly, the Bureau should communicate its expectations and inform participants on permissible and restricted actions during the event or demonstration.

column2: >3.1.1.2. The Bureau, through the PPB Demonstration Liaison or another designee, shall attempt to maintain communication with known event or demonstration organizers or the Person(s)-In-Charge before and during the event. &nbsp
column3: The Liaison shall maintain communications with the IC to keep them apprised of the situation.

column2: >3.1.1.3. The Bureau, through the Public Information Officer (PIO) or another designee, shall communicate through the use of social media and other conventional outlets to keep the public, including the crowd, informed throughout the event.&nbsp
>3.2. When appropriate, members should engage and interact with the crowd in a positive and non-confrontational manner.

>4.1.1. Where the Bureau learns of an event at least twenty-four hours prior to its commencement, the Assistant Chief of Operations and the precinct commander nearest to the event location shall determine if the event should be staffed using the precinct&rsquo
column3: s resources or city-wide Bureau resources.

column2: >4.1.1.1. Events that are small in crowd size, or for which credible information indicates that there is little concern of civil disturbance, shall generally be managed at the precinct level and staffed by the shift supervisor, who shall serve as the IC.

>4.1.1.1.1. If crowd behavior escalates to a level that poses a threat to public safety, peace or order during an event that is being managed by a shift supervisor acting as the IC, the shift supervisor must consult with a CMIC who will then determine if they (the CMIC) should assume command and request additional resources.

>4.1.1.2. Events that are anticipated to have a greater critical impact, require a significant police response, and/or have the potential to become a civil disturbance shall have a CMIC designated by the Assistant Chief of Operations as the IC.
>4.1.2. The IC shall determine the level of police response, if any is warranted.
>4.1.3. In accordance with the ICS, if the IC deems a police response necessary, the IC, or a designee, should develop an IAP for the demonstration or special event.
>4.1.3.1. If it is determined that basic Mobile Field Force (MFF) and bicycle units are not sufficient to manage the crowd, a CMIC shall be assigned to the event.
>4.1.3.2. Only a CMIC may activate RRT or Mass Arrest teams.
>4.1.3.2.1. If a shift supervisor is staffing an event as the IC, they shall consult with a CMIC prior to activating RRT.
>4.1.3.2.2. Activation of Mass Arrest requires the CMIC to notify the Detective Division to ensure mass-arrest resources are available.&nbsp
>4.2.1. Events that the Bureau learns of with less than twenty-four hours before the start of the event are deemed spontaneous.
>4.2.2. Many spontaneous events can be lawful and facilitated with appropriate police assistance.&nbsp
column3: A spontaneous or non-permitted event is not necessarily unlawful, nor does it automatically require a significant police response.

column2: >4.2.3. A supervisor at the precinct of occurrence shall respond to the event and determine if a police response is warranted.

>4.2.3.1. If a police response is warranted, the on-scene supervisor shall serve as the IC for the incident and attempt to engage the event or demonstration organizer in an effort to facilitate participants&rsquo
column3: lawful objectives and protect their right to assemble.

column2: >4.2.3.1.1. A Sergeant who is the first supervisor on scene of a spontaneous demonstration shall notify their Lieutenant, who may then respond to the scene and assume command.
>4.2.3.2. The on-scene supervisor (IC) may contact an RRT supervisor, the RRT commander or a CMIC to help determine an appropriate level of response.
>4.2.3.2.1. After consultation, if a higher level of police response is deemed necessary, a CMIC shall be called in and assume command.

>4.2.3.3. If crowd behavior during the event escalates to a level that poses a threat to public safety, peace or order during an event that is being managed by a shift supervisor, the shift supervisor must consult with a CMIC, who will then determine if they (the CMIC) should assume command.&nbsp
>4.3. Demonstrations may be broadcast to Bureau facilities by live video feed to provide situational awareness to the IC.&nbsp
column4: 181A.250, the broadcast will not be recorded unless and until a member has reasonable suspicion that a crime is being committed, at which time the member will communicate this information up the chain of command to the IC, who will make the decision whether to authorize recording to commence.&nbsp
column5: If a possible crime is captured on the recording, that recording will be forwarded to Bureau&rsquo
column6: s Detective Division for investigation and the District Attorney&rsquo
column8: A copy will also be furnished to the City Attorney&rsquo
column9: s office for the purpose of evaluating civil liability based on crimes charged or arrests made.&nbsp
column10: Pursuant to Oregon Administrative Rules regarding records retention, recordings that do not have evidentiary value or aid in internal investigations shall only be retained by the City Attorney&rsquo
column12: The Bureau will not keep a copy of any videos recorded under this Directive, and the IC will not authorize recording for the purposes of monitoring individuals or groups based solely on political&nbsp
column13: associations or religious or social views.

column1: 5. Police Response to Demonstrations and Special Events.

column2: >5.1. Prior to a demonstration or event, the IC shall make a determination regarding the appropriate level of police response and the necessary allocation of resources to manage an event.&nbsp
column3: Depending on the potential impact of the crowd (e.g., size, interference with commerce, street and pedestrian traffic, etc.), the Bureau may not need to be involved in the event.&nbsp

column2: >5.2. The priority of the Bureau is to allow demonstration and event participants to self-police and manage their own events.&nbsp
column3: To that end the IC shall monitor the event, weighing the totality of the circumstances to inform the decision to introduce police action to maintain public safety, peace and order.

column2: >5.2.1. When deciding whether to use certain police tactics within a crowd, the IC shall balance the benefits of such action(s) to maintain public safety, peace and order against the impact on the demonstration or event participants&rsquo
>5.2.2. The IC, or a designee, shall authorize the appropriate level of protective equipment based on several factors to include, but not limited to:
>5.2.2.4. Actual or credible threats or indicators of violent behavior,
>5.2.2.5. Actual or credible threats or indicators of criminal actions, and
>5.2.2.6. The potential impact or perceived effect that appearing in protective gear may have on the crowd.
>5.2.3. When practicable, the IC should attempt to position members in protective gear in locations that minimize visibility until deployment is necessary.&nbsp

column3: If crowd behavior presents a clear and present danger that threatens the public safety, peace or order, and the event can no longer be effectively managed through a minimal police presence, the IC may adjust crowd tactics to adequately respond.

column2: >5.3.1. When police action is necessary, members should endeavor to distinguish between individuals engaged in criminal behavior and demonstration or event participants who are peacefully and lawfully demonstrating.

column3: s assigned Demonstration Liaison, another IC-designated member and/or the member operating the sound truck shall, when feasible, attempt to convey the police action to the crowd via announcements and warnings.&nbsp
The Bureau shall de-escalate its response when it is safe and tactically feasible to do so.

column2: >6.1.1. Oversee the development, dissemination, and implementation of the IAP for the demonstration in accordance with this Directive and ICS
>6.1.2. Determine the mission and objectives and consider what crowd tactics are objectively reasonable under the totality of the circumstances
>6.1.3. When feasible, attempt to maintain communication, through the PPB Demonstration Liaison, with the Person-In-Charge, or their designee, during demonstrations
>6.1.4. Authorize the use of protective gear

>6.1.5. Ensure announcements communicated to the crowd are clear, consistent, lawful, and appropriate for the circumstances. The content and timing of the announcement shall be documented and, if feasible, shall be audio recorded
>6.2. The CMIC shall (in addition to the IC responsibilities):
>6.2.2. Authorize the deployment of riot control agents and/or special impact munitions, when objectively reasonable, to address civil disturbance and crowd dispersal.&nbsp
>6.3.1. Assist the IC in determining staffing levels, probable missions, and possible tactical strategies during the planning for the event
>6.3.2. Assign units to specific missions during the event to meet the objectives established by the IC.&nbsp
>6.4. The Detective Division Commander or Supervisor shall:
>6.4.1. Coordinate with the IC to determine the scale of the mass arrest team response
>6.4.2. Assign detectives to assist with mass arrests
>6.4.3. Manage the processing of all arrests pursuant to the Detective Division SOP
>6.4.4. Ensure that all required documentation for arrests is collected.&nbsp
>6.5.1. Verify that all members have the proper equipment
>6.5.2. Ensure that members are briefed prior to the start of the event
>6.5.3. Communicate orders from the IC or the Operations Section Chief to their assigned squad to ensure that the mission and objectives are appropriately executed.&nbsp
>6.6.1. Follow the directions of the sergeant
>6.6.2. Not take independent police action, unless exigent circumstances require immediate action for protecting themselves or others from physical harm.<span style=""font-size: 1.1em
>7.1. The Bureau may request assistance from other law enforcement agencies to sufficiently staff and respond to a demonstration or special event.&nbsp
>7.1.1. The Bureau IC, or their designee, shall appropriately brief outside agency personnel prior to their deployment.&nbsp
>7.1.2. The Bureau IC shall maintain the authority to determine tactical objectives
column3: direct the overall police response (all agencies)
column4: and determine, when objectively reasonable, how and when force may be used and when to deploy less lethal munitions to address civil disturbance and/or disperse the crowd.

column2: >7.1.3. The Bureau expects assisting agencies to act in accordance with the lawful orders of the Bureau IC
column4: conduct is subject to the outside agency&rsquo

column2: >8.1. When feasible, members shall make loud, intelligible and consistent announcements and warnings to the crowd.&nbsp
>8.2.1. Convey general information to the crowd in an effort to keep an event lawful
>8.2.2. Communicate targeted information to specific individuals to provide direction
>8.2.3. Serve as a de-escalation tool by directing and informing the crowd in an attempt to prevent the need for police action or the use of force.&nbsp
>8.3.1. Warnings are designed to allow the crowd time to comply with orders given from police members.&nbsp
column3: When tactically feasible and time permits, members shall issue a minimum of two warnings at reasonable intervals to notify the crowd of an impending order.

column2: >8.3.2. When issuing warnings, members should cite specific offenses and violations being committed and caution the crowd that these acts of civil disturbance will not be permitted and can result in arrest or necessitate the use of force.&nbsp
column3: An IC-designated member and/or the member operating the sound truck shall give clear directions in an attempt to reduce or eliminate the necessity for force.&nbsp
column4: Members shall issue a minimum of two warnings to alert the crowd of possible impending arrest or force, unless doing so would present a danger to the member(s) or others.

column2: >8.3.3. Members shall document the warnings in an appropriate police report, and if feasible, ensure the audio (e.g., date, time, announcing member, messages, etc.) confirmation received by identified staff on other end.

column3: 131.675, the IC may order the crowd dispersed when a demonstration or special event becomes a civil disturbance.

column2: >9.1.1. Before giving the order to disperse, the IC must consider whether dispersal unduly endangers the public, police or participants in the crowd.

>9.1.2. Prior to taking police action to disperse the crowd, and when tactically feasible and time reasonably permits, members shall issue a minimum of two warnings at reasonable intervals to allow the crowd to comply.&nbsp

>9.2. When the crowd has been ordered to disperse and does not heed repeated warnings, and no reasonable alternative is apparent, riot control agents (RCAs) and/or special impact munitions may be deployed to prevent violence, injury or property damage and to avoid a greater application of force.
>9.2.1. These weapons shall only be used at the direction of the CMIC and when avenues of escape (i.e., clear path or route) are available to the crowd.&nbsp
column3: Pursuant to this policy and Directive 1010.00, Use of Force, members must issue warnings prior to deployment.&nbsp

column2: >9.3. Force shall only be used in accordance with Directive 1010.00, Use of Force.
>10.1. Members shall not take the following actions to disperse a crowd:
>10.2. Members shall not deploy specialty impact munitions or aerosol restraints indiscriminately into a crowd.

column4: The Bureau shall not use mounted patrol units (MPUs) against passively resistant demonstrators who are sitting or lying down.&nbsp
Motor vehicles shall not be intentionally brought into contact with protestors (i.e., to push or strike).

column2: >11.1. The failure to comply with the lawful order to disperse can transform otherwise legal conduct into criminal conduct if the protest has been determined to be a civil disturbance by the IC or if the crowd has left from a certain location.&nbsp
column3: Members may be justified in detaining individuals engaged in civil disturbance after providing a lawful order to disperse followed by a reasonable opportunity to comply with that order. &nbsp

column4: Absent exigent circumstances, arrests should only be made when authorized by the IC.&nbsp
Careful consideration should be given to the timing, location, and method of the arrest and resources available.&nbsp
To effect arrests, members must be able to articulate the individualized probable cause for the arrest of each person.&nbsp
Media or legal observers will not be arrested solely for their role in observing, capturing, and/or reporting on demonstrations or events.&nbsp
column5: Members will not interfere with media or legal observers performing their respective functions, so long as they are performed in a safe manner and in compliance with police orders.&nbsp
column6: However, such persons must comply with all police orders and maybe subject to arrest for failure to do so.

column2: >13.1.1. Write an After Action in accordance with Directive(s) 905.00, Non-Force After Action Reporting, or 1010.00, Use of Force, if force was used
>13.1.2. Review any uses of force by other agencies&rsquo
column3: personnel as part of the overall incident after action report

column2: >13.1.3. Write an overall police report that describes the major decisions made by the police during the incident in accordance with Directive 900.00, General Reporting Guidelines
>13.1.4. Ensure all other applicable pertinent reports are submitted as required by Directive 900.00, General Reporting Guidelines, and 1010.00, Use of Force
>13.1.5. Hold a formal debrief of the event to discuss the overall plan, tactics, staffing and areas of improvement.&nbsp
column3: The debrief should include key supervisory member participants in the event.&nbsp

column2: >13.2. The Detective Division Commander or Supervisor shall:
>13.2.1. Ensure coordination with the District Attorney&rsquo
column3: s Office when arrests are made.&nbsp

column2: >13.3.1. The supervisor shall not independently direct management or crowd control tactics without the authorization of the IC, unless exigent circumstances require immediate action.

>13.3.2. At the end of the event, the lead supervisor of each squad shall conduct a debriefing of the incident with their personnel and complete an appropriate police report in accordance with Directive 900.00, General R",https://www.portlandoregon.gov/police/article/649358

0600 - Field Operations,Field Operations,699105,0630.25 Cadet Program,ARB-PPB-0630.25,0630.25,2,,2018-10-01 16:04:50 UTC,2018-10-01 15:58:00 UTC,A,,"

630.25, Cadet Program
• Law Enforcement Cadet Application (PPB Cadet Program Website)
<li>Law Enforcement Cadet Program Standard Operating Procedure&nbsp

column2: s (PPB) Law Enforcement Cadet Program (LECP) is designed to acquaint young individuals between the ages of 16 and 20 with PPB
column3: instill in those participants an understanding and appreciation of the justice system, law, and professional ethics as they apply to the field of law enforcement
column4: and to help interested individuals develop skills and knowledge to assist them with a career in law enforcement.&nbsp
column5: Interested participants are encouraged to view the Bureau&rsquo
column6: s Cadet Program website for more information regarding membership requirements.&nbsp

column2: >1.1. The Cadet Coordinator is a sworn member who is responsible for managing the activities and organization of the LECP.&nbsp
>1.1.1. Report to the Youth Services Division (YSD) Captain (or the Responsibility Unit (RU) Commander responsible for overseeing the LECP if it is moved to another division).

>1.1.2. Perform the duties outlined in this Directive and the LECP Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) with the assistance of sworn Bureau member volunteers in Lead Advisor and Associate Advisor (&ldquo
>1.1.2.1. In matters involving the Cadet program, the Cadet Coordinator has ultimate decision making authority over the Advisors.
>1.1.3. Secure Cadet records and retain in accordance with the City of Portland&rsquo
column3: s records retention requirements for the Police Bureau.

column2: >1.1.4. Oversee Cadet service requests and direct Cadets to the appropriate posts at the precincts.
>1.1.5. Coordinate initial training and activities involving multiple posts and ensure proper supervision during those activities.

column3: s activity log at the end of each month to ensure that they are not participating in more than the legal limit of hours allowed for activities.

column2: >1.1.6.1. The Cadet Coordinator shall check each Cadet&rsquo
column3: s log and verify that an Advisor has signed off on training and/or activities observed.

column2: >1.1.7. Maintain a list of approved Lead Advisors and Associate Advisors.

>1.1.7.1. No member may serve as an Advisor if they have been subject to disciplinary action based upon the use of force or mistreatment of people with mental illness within the three preceding years, or twice in the preceding five years.
>1.1.7.2. Final approving authority of Advisors resides with the YSD Captain.
>1.1.8. Evaluate any complaints received against an Advisor and make a recommendation to the YSD Captain regarding whether the Advisor&rsquo
column3: s continued participation in the LECP is appropriate.

column2: >1.1.8.1. Authority to suspend or remove an Advisor from the LECP belongs exclusively to the YSD Captain.
>1.1.9. Evaluate any complaints received against a Cadet or any other information that raises concerns about a Cadet&rsquo
column3: s behavior or performance and make a recommendation to the YSD Captain regarding whether the Cadet&rsquo
column4: s continued participation in the LECP is appropriate.

column2: >1.1.9.1. Authority to suspend or separate a Cadet from the LECP belongs exclusively to the YSD Captain.&nbsp

column1: 2. Lead Advisors and Associate Lead Advisors.

column2: >2.1. Lead Advisors are responsible for coordinating on-going training for Cadets under the supervision of the Cadet Coordinator.&nbsp
>2.2. When directly supervising Cadets, Advisors shall direct Cadets to not take law enforcement action and shall not provide Cadets access to Bureau weapons or police reports.
>2.2.1. Advisors shall not allow Cadets under the age of 18 to operate police vehicles on any premises open to the public.&nbsp
>2.3. Advisors shall review and sign off on each Cadet&rsquo
column3: s activity log at the end of each month.&nbsp

column2: >2.4. Advisors have a duty to forward alleged complaints and report complaints against another advisor to the Cadet Coordinator as soon as practicable.&nbsp
column3: Internal Affairs level complaints shall be handled in accordance with Directive 330.00, Internal Affairs, Complaint Intake, and Processing.&nbsp

column2: >3.1. Cadets shall adhere to all applicable Bureau directives and SOPs. &nbsp
column3: Cadets shall follow lawful orders, commands, and instructions of sworn members.

column2: >3.1.1. Cadets shall maintain a personal log of all Cadet activities conducted and have an Advisor review and sign at the end of each month. This includes ride-alongs, attendance at trainings, and participation in community outreach events.&nbsp
column3: Cadets shall then forward their log to the Cadet Coordinator at the end of each month.&nbsp

column2: >3.1.2. Cadets shall not take law enforcement action as they do not have any police powers.
>3.1.3. Cadets shall not handle Bureau weapons in any capacity, except while under supervision during training.
>3.1.4. Cadets 18 years of age and older may access LEDS and NCIC programs after completing the appropriate Bureau training and certification and while under the supervision of a sworn Bureau member.
>3.1.5. Cadets over 18 years of age may operate a police vehicle in the field as directed by a sworn member.&nbsp
column3: Cadets under 18 years of age shall only operate police vehicles during training.

column2: >3.1.5.1. Cadets operating police vehicles shall not perform emergency vehicle operations (code 3) at any time.
>3.1.5.2. Cadets operating police vehicles shall not become involved in pursuits in any capacity.&nbsp
>4.1. Cadets shall obey all directions given to them by the Bureau member as described in Directive 630.30, Community Policing Citizen Ride-Along Program.&nbsp
>4.2. When responding to emergency situations or active criminal scenes, members with ride- alongs shall determine whether it is safe to allow a Cadet to observe from a distance.&nbsp
column3: If the member has safety concerns, they will drop off the Cadet at an appropriate location.&nbsp

column2: >4.2.1. Members shall immediately notify a supervisor if they drop off a Cadet.&nbsp
>4.3. The Bureau member or Cadet may terminate a ride-along at any time.&nbsp
>4.4. Members shall follow the procedures set forth in Directive 630.05, Vehicle Interventions and Pursuits, when community members or Cadets are present.&nbsp

0600 - Field Operations,Field Operations,699114,0660.32 Agent/ Informant Processing,ARB-PPB-0660.32,0660.32,2,,2018-10-01 16:20:16 UTC,2018-10-01 16:06:00 UTC,A,,"

660.32, Agent/Informant Processing
<li>Agent: A law enforcement officer operating in an undercover status.&nbsp
<li>Confidential Reliable Informant (CRI): An individual who has established reliability by working with members in developing criminal information or evidence, usually as an informant.&nbsp

<li>Cooperating Witness: An individual (the person may be a witness or criminal suspect) who provides immediate and case specific information to members for the purposes of furthering an initial criminal investigation.&nbsp
<li>Informant: An individual working for a member in an undercover status.<strong style=""font-size: 1.1em
1. The Drugs and Vice Division (DVD) has the responsibility for maintaining accurate information regarding the status of informants used by the Police Bureau.
column2: In the interest of consistency and to ensure the appropriate vetting of informants necessary to maintain the integrity of the program the DVD Manager or sworn designee will approve all Police Bureau informants prior to use. &nbsp
column3: Anyone working as an informant for a member will be processed in the following manner before funds may be disbursed.<strong style=""font-size: 1.1em

column2: >1.1. The Checklist will be completed by the member processing the informant prior to submitting the informant package to their supervisor for approval.&nbsp
>1.2. The informant file will contain as a minimum:
>1.2.6. Computerized Criminal History (CCH) and RegJIN printout.&nbsp
>1.3. All forms will be filled out completely. If an item does not apply, indicate not applicable (N/A) in the appropriate place.&nbsp
>1.4. The entire informant file will be maintained by the originating Responsibility Unit (RU) as an active file.
>1.4.1. When an informant has not been utilized for a period of one (1) year, the file will be designated as inactive.
>1.4.2. To maintain accurate informant status when an informant is designated as inactive the informant&rsquo
column3: s file will be transferred to DVD for inclusion in the master DVD inactive informant file.

column2: >1.4.3. The file will be maintained by DVD and will be subject to purging in accordance with state records retention laws, unless the informant is re-activated by a member prior to the purge date.
>1.4.4. Members may re-activate an informant by submitting a newly completed informant packet with a new Informant File Checklist including CCH and RegJIN updates.
>1.4.5. The immediate use and payment of an inactive informant is not precluded, as long as the informant file is updated during the calendar month in which the re-activation occurs.
>1.4.6. Inactive informant files will be purged after a period of five (5) years.&nbsp

>1.5. The informant file is accessible only to the RU Manager or designees, and supervisors when evidence funds are audited. All requests to view any informant files by outside parties (e.g., a judge or deputy district attorney [DA]) will be forwarded to the DVD Manager for response in order to ensure program consistency.&nbsp

>2.1. A profile will be completed on each informant receiving or using evidence funds, formalized case consideration or is otherwise under the direction of a member actively working on a criminal investigation. &nbsp
column3: Cooperating witnesses, who provide immediate and case specific information to members during an initial criminal investigation, are not subject to this requirement.&nbsp

column2: >2.2. A code name will be assigned to the informant by the initiating member. &nbsp
column3: The code name will be an alias
column4: true names will not be used. &nbsp
column5: The code name will include full first, middle and last names, and will be used in all record keeping and receipt transactions involving the informant.&nbsp

column2: >2.3. The informant must be present when the form is completed and will be required to sign their true name, full code name, and affix the right-hand, index fingerprint on the bottom of the form.&nbsp
>2.4. A current photograph and copies of the informant&rsquo
column3: s criminal history, if any, will be attached to the form.&nbsp

column2: >2.5. Reliable identification must be obtained in the event the informant has no record.&nbsp
>3.1. The waiver must be read by the informant, completed and signed. &nbsp
column3: Each item must be initialed by the informant and witnessed by a supervisor.&nbsp

column2: >3.2. The waiver is to be retained and solely accessed by the RU Manager in a locked file cabinet, separate from the Informant Moniker and Reliability form. &nbsp
column3: Any changes in information or documentation regarding an informant will be relayed to the RU Manager immediately for accurate maintenance of the form.&nbsp

column2: >4.1. This document will be completed on all informants receiving or using evidence funds.&nbsp
>4.2. A supervisory sergeant or above will be responsible for completing the form and setting up the Informant Moniker and Productivity File.&nbsp
>4.3. The informant must sign the exemplar section (three signatures), which will be witnessed by a supervisor.&nbsp
>4.4. All documentation dealing with the informant&rsquo
column3: s reliability will be maintained in this file. This includes Part I, the white copy of the Evidence Fund Accounting Receipt (EFAR), which contains information on the informant&rsquo

column2: >4.5. The RU Manager, or their sworn designee, is responsible for maintaining the file up-to-date, checking informant signatures against exemplars, and filing agent/informant receipts.&nbsp
>4.6. Each time a supervisor checks the file
column3: they will initial and date the Supervisor&rsquo
column4: s Review Section of the form.&nbsp

column2: >5.1. This report contains information useful in deciding whether or not to use the informant, and will be completed in conjunction with the Informant Profile form. &nbsp
column3: Supervisors and managers from each Responsibility Unit employing informants will review the entire informant file before delivering the file to a DVD supervisor. &nbsp
column4: DVD supervisors will review the file to ensure that they are completed in a manner that is consistent with the appropriate vetting of informants necessary to maintain the integrity of the program before forwarding the file to the DVD Manager for final review.&nbsp
column5: If an informant has been arrested for or convicted of violent person felony crimes, sex offenses, or has other criminal history that would tend to greatly undermine public confidence in the informant program, the DVD supervisor will review the informant file with the appropriate deputy DA for their input and information prior to the DVD Manager&rsquo
column8: s Office review, the DVD Manager may deny the use of such informants or may require control officer restrictions or case specific restrictions for informants who have problematic criminal histories.&nbsp

column3: s criminal history should be summarized on this form from a review of the CCH and RegJIN printout.&nbsp

column2: >5.3. If an informant has worked for other agencies in the past, contact the agency(s) and summarize the informant&rsquo
>5.4. Supervisors and managers will indicate approval and route to the DVD Manager for final approval. &nbsp
column3: All informant files will be hand delivered to DVD for review.&nbsp

column2: >5.5. Supervisors or managers who find that a potential informant is unsuitable for employment may deny informant use at their RU level without forwarding the informant packet to DVD for final review.
>6.1. When different RUs use the same CRI, each unit will maintain a moniker file. &nbsp
column3: All such cases will be approved by the DVD Manager. &nbsp
column4: Requests for the multiple unit use of a CRI will be made by inter-office memorandum through channels to the DVD Manager.&nbsp

column2: >7.1. DVD will issue a semi-annual True Name/Code Number Index Log by RU that lists the informants currently in an active or inactive status. &nbsp
column3: All units will maintain this log when using informants and/or disbursing evidence funds.&nbsp

column2: >7.2. This log will be justified each July and January with the files maintained by the RU. &nbsp
column3: If there are discrepancies, the DVD administrative sergeant will be notified immediately in order to update the master files.&nbsp

column2: >7.3. This log will be maintained in a file folder with the Informant Profile and Liability form file.&nbsp

>7.4. The log will contain informant code numbers, complete true names, complete code names, dates, and Department of Public Safety Standards and Training number (DPSST #) of initiating member/investigator.&nbsp

>8.1. An informant code number must be assigned by a DVD supervisory sergeant prior to any informants receiving or expending evidence funds or being under the direction of a member who is actively working on a criminal investigation.&nbsp
>8.2. To maintain uniform accountability, the code number will be a unique sequential agent/informant number that is not assigned to any other informant. &nbsp
column3: This will preclude an informant who works for more than one division from having different code number.&nbsp

column2: >8.3. The DVD supervisory sergeant will also run a check of the informant&rsquo
column3: s true name through the Western States Identification Network (WSIN) database.&nbsp

column2: >8.4. The code name will be an alias. &nbsp
column3: True names will not be used. &nbsp
column4: The name will be a complete first, middle and last name. &nbsp
column5: Initials and short names will not be used.&nbsp

column2: >8.5. The code number will be used in all receipt and record-keeping transactions (to include inter-office memos) involving the agent/informant.&nbsp
>9.1. The DVD Manager may waive the above process in special situations where the information is of such value it would be counter-productive to force the informant to identify themselves. &nbsp
column3: Exceptions will be kept to a minimum and closely supervised. The DVD Manager will review all such cases with the Assistant Chief of the Investigations Branch.&nbsp

column2: >9.2. Exceptions may also be authorized by a RU Manager for one-time payments for information. &nbsp
column3: An EFAR will be completed and the informant will sign using their true name. &nbsp
column4: Exceptional payments will be reviewed by the DVD Manager for final approval after authorization by the involved RU Manager.

column2: >9.3. Each division disbursing evidence funds will set up a file with an assigned code number (001) and a code name entitled &ldquo
column5: All Informant EFAR will be filed in this folder in chronological date order.

column2: >9.3.1. If the RU Manager grants an exception, the member disbursing funds will complete a receipt, printing in the code name Informant Exception.
>9.3.2. The code number for the informant exception file is 001 and will be used as the code number for all such exceptional payments.

column3: s name will be noted in the comment section of the receipt and the EFAR will be accompanied by an inter-office memorandum through channels from the control officer to the RU Manager and the DVD Manager explaining the justification for the exception.

column2: >9.3.4. All other productivity information will be completed on the receipt.
>9.3.5. Informant Moniker and Reliability forms will not be completed on Informant Exceptions.&nbsp

>10.1. Receipts contain information on evidence funds disbursal, and informant productivity. The EFAR is an important link in the audit trail for evidence funds and in developing information related to criminal investigations. &nbsp
column3: For these reasons, all member/investigators are reminded that:

column2: >10.1.1. A signed receipt must be obtained for all fund disbursal to informants.
>10.1.2. All information possible must be included on the receipt.
>10.1.3. Receipts must be processed and turned over to a member&rsquo
column3: s supervisor on the same day as the funds are disbursed.

column2: >10.1.4. An EFAR or written report (police report or inter-office memorandum) must be completed for all informant productivity when an expense is incurred or a material step is made toward fulfilling formal case consideration. &nbsp
column3: These receipts and/or reports will be filed in an informant&rsquo
column4: s moniker and productivity file as soon as possible after the expense or transaction.

column2: >10.1.5. Informant code numbers and code names will not be mentioned in police reports. They will be used when completing the monthly EFAR.
>10.1.6. An informant will sign the full code name, including middle name, when signing a receipt.
>10.1.7. All divisions using informants must enter the following information into the informant EFAR database from EFAR on a monthly basis:
>10.1.7.5. Amount paid (not to include buy money).
>10.1.8. Divisions using informants will be required to provide DVD with a current list of personnel, including I.D., who require access to this database. &nbsp
column3: DVD will coordinate the granting of access to the informant EFAR database. &nbsp
column4: Those members who determine their informant is being used by another division must contact the control officer of that division.&nbsp

column1: 11. Operations with an undercover operative (member or non-police person working in a specified undercover operation): Agents/Informants.

column2: >11.1. Agent/informants will be assigned a control officer who is responsible for fund disbursement and accounting for evidence funds used by the agent/informant. &nbsp
column3: The control officer will also be responsible for monitoring, directing and controlling the activities of the agent/informant.&nbsp

column2: >11.2. Under normal circumstances, members will adhere to Directive 660.30, Evidence Funds Use, and account for evidence funds under the prescribed procedures set forth.&nbsp

>11.3. Undercover members (agents) who, due to assignment, are unable to work from the division office draw funds in person, or process property or evidence in person, will be assigned a control officer. &nbsp
column3: The control officer will be responsible for fund disbursement and accounting for evidence funds used by the member. &nbsp
column4: The control officer will also be responsible for monitoring, directing and controlling the activities of the member. &nbsp
column5: Undercover members used in this capacity should be under exceptional circumstances and pre-approved by an RU Manager.&nbsp

column2: >11.4. Disbursement to an undercover operative in the form of a monthly retainer is authorized under the following conditions:
>11.4.1. A written request is made to the RU Manager, which includes at least the following:
>11.4.1.3. The duration and review dates of the contract.&nbsp
>11.4.2. A DA has reviewed the request for appropriateness for prosecution.&nbsp
>11.4.3. A weekly report is submitted to the RU giving the results obtained by the operative and the total weekly cost for service.&nbsp
>11.5. Evidence funds to be disbursed to the undercover operative will be drawn by the control officer in their own name. &nbsp
>11.5.2. Ensuring the undercover operative accounts for expenditures, obtains proper receipts and supporting documents.
>11.5.3. Preparing a monthly EFAR for the undercover operative showing dates, amounts and total funds the operative received and/or returned.
>11.5.4. Accounting for those funds on the control officer&rsquo
>11.5.5. Assisting the operative in report preparation.

column3: s EFAR at the end of the month.

column2: >11.5.7. Handling and processing any evidence used, purchased or recovered by the operative.&nbsp
>11.6. The undercover operative will be responsible for:
>11.6.3. Documentation for the EFAR to cover expenditures.&nbsp

0600 - Field Operations,Field Operations,707677,0660.10 Property and Evidence Procedures,ARB-PPB-0660.10,0660.10,2,,2019-01-02 16:37:08 UTC,2018-12-30 08:01:00 UTC,A,,"

660.10 Property and Evidence Procedures
• Oregon State Police (OSP) Forensic Sciences Request (FSR) Form (Form 49)
• Portland Police Bureau (PPB) Property and Evidence Division (PED) Evidence Transfer Form
• PPB PED Order for Property Release Form

<li>Evidence: An article(s) taken into police custody that may furnish proof that an offense has been committed and/or certain person(s) committed an offense, or an article(s) taken into police custody that would tend to show a person(s) did not commit a crime.&nbsp
<li>Found property: An article(s) accepted into police custody that has been lost or abandoned and not connected with a known or suspected criminal offense.&nbsp

column2: s property: Personal property belonging to an arrested suspect that is not needed as evidence.&nbsp

column1: <li>Safekeeping Property: An article(s) that is voluntarily relinquished to police custody or taken to prevent serious harm to any person or property under the provisions of ORS&sect
<li>Satellite Property Room: An area at designated Police Bureau sites set aside for the temporary storage of evidence and property.&nbsp
<li>This directive establishes standardized procedures for seizing and storing evidence and/or property in accordance with Property and Evidence Division (PED) practices.&nbsp
column2: Additionally, this directive mandates procedures for requests concerning the testing, transfer, and release of evidence or property.<strong>&nbsp
>1.1. Any member who takes possession of property and/or evidence shall complete a PED Property/Evidence Receipt (&ldquo

column3: Members shall provide the following required information in the appropriate spaces on the form:

column4: s address and zip code, when known.
s address and zip code, when known.

column3: If the owner is unknown, members shall write &ldquo
When found property is received from a finder, the finder&rsquo
column4: s name shall be placed in the space marked &ldquo
column6: and the member shall issue the finder the yellow copy of the PED receipt.

column3: A full description of each item submitted, including serial numbers, if applicable.
Firearms require documentation of the serial number, make, type, model, caliber, importer and country of origin.
For currency, the exact dollar and cents amount recovered and the country of origin of the currency.&nbsp
column4: Members are not required to document serial numbers for recovered currency.

column3: Delivery destination (e.g., Property Evidence Division, Oregon State Police (OSP) Crime Lab, Forensic Evidence Division [FED], or if &ldquo
column5: , members must describe). Members must include the locker location and number on the receipt.&nbsp

column3: Members shall handle copies of the PED receipt as follows:
White copy shall be forwarded to the Records Division (Records).

Yellow copy shall be given to the person the property or evidence was taken from. If the person whose property was impounded is not available, the member shall leave the yellow copy at the scene where the property was found.
Pink copy shall accompany the property/evidence.
When delivering items to the satellite property rooms, members shall leave the pink copy of the PED receipt in the designated tray.
If property is released at the scene, members shall make an appropriate notation on the receipt and forward the pink copy to PED.
Members shall use separate receipts and separate packaging for items that are delivered to different locations.
Members shall forward all copies of voided receipts to PED.&nbsp
Members must complete and attach a property tag or evidence tag to items that are not packaged in evidence bags.&nbsp
Members shall write identifying information on the evidence bag/tag to include: property evidence receipt number, date, PPB case number, delivering member&rsquo
column4: s name and DPSST number, and content description.&nbsp

column3: Members shall deliver property/evidence to PED, a satellite property room, FED, the Oregon State Crime Lab, or the Gun Task Force (GTF) prior to the end of their shift.<strong>&nbsp

Firearms and cartridge casings that are eligible for Integrated Ballistics Identification System (IBIS) and National Integrated Ballistic Information Network (NIBIN) processing shall be delivered to GTF prior to delivery and submission to PED and/or FED. &nbsp
column4: Members shall refer to Section 7, Processing Firearms, for eligibility requirements.&nbsp

column3: In emergent situations, property/evidence may need to be delivered to another location for investigative purposes

column4: Evidence delivered to a satellite property room shall be delivered to FED by PED personnel.&nbsp

column6: The Forensics Processing Request Form must be affixed to the front of the FED Incoming Evidence Locker where the evidence is placed. &nbsp
column7: If DNA testing is also requested, members must complete an OSP Forensics Sciences Request (FSR) Form and attach it to the evidence.&nbsp

column3: The packaging in which drugs, drug paraphernalia, and money are recovered may be fingerprinted but the content of the packages themselves may not be delivered to FED.&nbsp

column3: When contents of a bag are repackaged in a separate bag, the name of the person removing the original contents and repackaging the original content into new bags must be noted on a tag placed both on the original packaging and the repackaging.&nbsp

column3: The packaging for Fentanyl or Fentanyl-related items shall only be accepted by FED if delivered by a sworn Drugs and Vice Division (DVD) member.&nbsp

column3: Members shall only deliver firearms directly to the GTF for IBIS/NIBIN processing if the firearm(s) is listed below and is considered evidence, found property, or surrendered.&nbsp

During a firearm investigation, if a member identifies a need for biological or forensic evidence collection, either of the following must occur:

If DNA is needed, members shall not touch the firearm and must contact the on-duty uniform Gang Enforcement Team (GET), on-duty Gun Violence Response Team (GVRT), or page out the on-call Gun Task Force (GTF) member 24/7 to coordinate DNA collection and processing.&nbsp

column6: Investigations led by the Robbery Detail or Homicide Detail are an exception, and specific direction shall be made by the Detective Sergeant. &nbsp

column3: Members shall deliver eligible firearms and all spent casings directly to the GTF during regular business hours or the secured drop box at the GTF after-hours.&nbsp

column4: Members may contact the GTF, PED, or the OSP Crime Lab with any questions about IBIS/NIBIN processing.

column3: Once the IBIS/NIBIN process is complete, GTF personnel shall deliver and submit the firearm(s) to PED as soon as practical, but no later than 96 hours.
Firearms not listed above that require fingerprinting and/or photographing shall be delivered directly to PED or FED.
Members shall deliver any firearm not requiring IBIS/NIBIN or FED processing directly to PED or any satellite property room locker.
Members shall ensure that firearms are unloaded and rendered safe for handling. &nbsp
column4: If a firearm cannot be made safe by unloading and securing the action/cylinder open, or if there is any question as to whether the firearm is loaded, the member shall attach a red &ldquo

column3: Members shall refer to the PED Officer Packaging Manual for instructions on packaging firearms and ammunition.&nbsp
PPB members should be aware that members of the public may surrender a dangerous or deadly weapon for destruction to any on-duty sworn member at any precinct.&nbsp

Members must ensure a declaration from the individual is annotated on a property receipt. The declaration should include the statement: &ldquo

If an individual chooses to surrender a weapon anonymously, the member shall still accept the weapon(s) and provide or attempt to provide a receipt.
Members shall deliver the surrendered firearm(s) directly to the GTF for IBIS/NIBIN processing if the firearm(s) meets eligibility listed in Section 7.1.1.1 or 7.1.1.2.&nbsp

column4: Members shall package these weapons in accordance with the PED Officer Packaging Manual.&nbsp
Members shall refer to Section 7 for information regarding surrendering weapons for destruction.&nbsp
Members who take possession of alcohol are encouraged to photograph and then release or dispose of the property unless it contains forensic evidence.&nbsp
column5: Members shall upload photographs to DIMS in accordance with Directive 640.02, Photography and Digital Imaging.&nbsp

column3: With the exception of evidence samples collected by DVD at scenes of illegal drug labs, hazardous or noxious materials shall not be accepted by or stored in any PED facility due to the health risk posed by exposure.&nbsp

column5: Members encountering hazardous or noxious materials that are not part of an illegal drug lab shall contact BOEC, which shall then notify the Portland Fire Bureau Hazardous Materials Team (HazMat).&nbsp

column3: DVD personnel shall package lab samples in accordance with the PED Officer Packaging Manual.
DVD personnel shall issue PED receipts and complete an FSR Form for all samples taken.&nbsp
column4: Members shall deliver samples and forms to the crime lab during business hours or to PED during non-business hours using the call-out procedure.

column3: Members shall deliver contaminated firearms (e.g., exposed to drug lab chemicals) from scenes of illegal drugs labs to a PED facility.&nbsp
column4: All other contaminated articles, including paperwork, shall not be accepted or stored at a PED facility.

column3: Members shall not transport contaminated articles, excluding contaminated firearms, from scenes of illegal drug labs in any Bureau vehicle. &nbsp

Contaminated firearms shall not be available for further investigation or viewing purposes unless handled by DVD personnel wearing the same level of protective gear that was worn during the initial processing.&nbsp
Items that have been contaminated with blood or other body fluids are considered bio-hazardous
column4: members shall package these items in accordance with the PED Officer Packaging Manual.&nbsp

column3: Members must deliver items that are wet with blood or other body fluids directly to PED during business hours or to the biohazard shed at the Rivergate Vehicle Storage Facility (RVS) after business hours. &nbsp
column4: Members shall leave the pink copy of the PED receipt at RVS. &nbsp
column5: Members shall not leave bio-hazardous items at any other property/evidence facility.

column3: Members may deliver items contaminated with blood or other body fluids that are dry to PED or any satellite property room locker.&nbsp
Syringes present a serious health risk and must be handled with extreme care
column4: members shall discard all syringes except those that are essential for prosecution purposes.

column3: Members shall discard unnecessary syringes into approved sharps containers only.
Members shall not deliver syringes or parts of syringes to the crime lab unless authorized by the Deputy District Attorney (DDA) in advance.
Members shall place syringes being submitted as evidence to the crime lab or PED inside plastic syringe holders. &nbsp
column4: The crime lab and PED shall only accept syringes packaged in plastic syringe holders.&nbsp

column2: >10.5. Explosives, bomb-making materials, ammunition .50 caliber or larger and commercial size fireworks shall not be accepted or stored at any PED facility. &nbsp

Illegal fireworks that fill less than a regular-sized paper grocery sack may be placed in any PED facility.
Members shall place larger quantities in the orange wooden box adjacent to the bomb room on L-1 in the Justice Center. &nbsp
column4: If that box is full, members shall contact EDU via the Dispatch Coordinator (DC) for disposition instructions. &nbsp

column3: Improvised, homemade, or modified fireworks shall not be accepted or stored in any property/evidence facility. &nbsp

column3: Gasoline shall not be accepted or stored at any property/evidence facility.
Members must ensure fuel containers and small engines with gas tanks (e.g., lawn mowers, chain saws, generators) are emptied prior to delivery.&nbsp

Members are encouraged to determine ownership of found property and return it, if time and circumstances permit. &nbsp

0600 - Field Operations,Field Operations,713766,0635.20 Community Member Observation of Police,ARB-PPB-0635.20,0635.20,2,,2019-02-28 19:58:33 UTC,2019-03-01 08:01:00 UTC,A,,"

635.20, Community Member Observation of Police
<li>Faraday bag: A bag that ensures portable digital devices are secure from any external interceptions, and prevents remote wiping of information, tracking, and bugging.&nbsp
<li>Media: Storage source for visual or audio recordings, whether by film, analog, or digital means.&nbsp
<li>Recording: Capturing of visual images, or sounds, including spoken words that are normally audible, or both, by means of a video camera, cell phone, audio recorder, or other device.&nbsp

column2: s possessory or ownership interests in property.&nbsp

>1. This policy provides guidelines for handling situations in which members of the public observe, photograph, video or audio record members of the Portland Police Bureau performing official duties. &nbsp
column3: Members should assume they are being audio or video recorded at all times when on duty in a public place.&nbsp

column2: >2. All persons have rights under state and federal law to observe and record police officers performing official duties, so long as that person&rsquo
column3: s actions do not interfere with the member&rsquo
column4: s duties or the safety of members or others, are consistent with reasonable restrictions, do not amount to criminal trespass, or otherwise violate the law.&nbsp

column2: >3. Persons may observe or record from any public place or any private property where the person has the legal right to be present. &nbsp
column3: However, this directive does not give any person permission to impede the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic or to disregard reasonable restrictions. &nbsp
column4: Members shall not prohibit or intentionally interfere with lawful observations or recordings except as provided in this directive.&nbsp
column5: Any recordings that are deemed to be evidence of a crime or relevant to an investigation shall only be collected, seized, or viewed in accordance with this directive and state and federal law.

column2: >1. Observing or Recording Law Enforcement Activity.

column4: The right of persons to observe or record law enforcement activity is not absolute and is subject to reasonable time, place, and manner restrictions. &nbsp
column5: Examples of such time, place, and manner restrictions include, but are not limited to:
Establishing a perimeter beyond which persons may not go
Requiring a person to keep a specified amount of distance between themselves and the persons or objects they seek to observe or film
Requiring a person to observe or record from a location that does not interfere with police operations

column4: While observing or recording, persons cannot interfere with law enforcement activity.&nbsp
column5: Examples of interference may include, but are not limited to:
Intentional and persistent attempts to distract or communicate with a witness or suspect with whom the police are speaking or engaging
Direct physical intervention or breaching the specified amount of distance established by a member
Repeated attempts to engage a member with questions or interruptions, thereby dividing the attention of the member to the matter at hand
Intentionally impeding the movement of emergency equipment or personnel
Inciting others to violate any law or any lawful command
Any action by the person that jeopardizes the safety or security of a member, victim, witness, suspect, or third party.&nbsp

column4: Members may require a person recording police activities to maintain a reasonable distance from that police activity. &nbsp
column5: Members shall consider the totality of the circumstances regarding the particular police activity in establishing a reasonable distance. &nbsp
column6: Members shall not establish or increase a distance for the sole purpose of discouraging or interfering with the lawful recording or observation of police activities. &nbsp
column7: Members are allowed to establish a distance that reasonably protects the privacy of any verbal communication between or among members, victims, witnesses, suspects, or third parties for their safety and the safety of members and others.&nbsp

column4: Whenever practical, members should give clear and concise warnings to persons recording police activities when the person&rsquo
column6: unlawful, Accompanying the warnings, whenever practical, a member should give clear directions on what a person can do to be compliant and continue recording.&nbsp
column7: For example, rather than simply directing a person to &ldquo
column9: a member should advise the person from where or at what distance the person may continue lawfully recording or observing the law enforcement activity.&nbsp

column5: s observation or recording continues to interfere with law enforcement activities or a member believes that the recording(s) may contain evidence of or information concerning the commission of a Measure 11 offense, when practical, the on-scene member shall request that a supervisor respond to the scene.

Under exigent circumstances, a member may take action to stop a community member from recording prior to communicating with their supervisor and shall document in their report articulable reasons for doing so.&nbsp
column6: Members will notify a supervisor as soon as practical after the exigency is resolved.&nbsp

column4: Members may not order or coerce a person to show them recordings that have been made of law enforcement activities. &nbsp
column5: But members may ask persons for consent to seize and view recordings.&nbsp
Members may seize recording devices and media if:

column4: The person recording consents to the seizure

column2: >3.2.1.1.1. A member obtaining consent shall have the person consenting fill out the written voluntary consent form and attach it to their report

column4: Exigent circumstances exist to seize the recording device or media. Exigent circumstances require probable cause to believe the recording device or media contains evidence of or information concerning the commission of a Measure 11 offense, and the member must objectively believe that immediate seizure is necessary to prevent the destruction or tampering of such evidence contained on the recording device or media. &nbsp
column5: The fact a recording device or media is capable of being deleted does not by itself create an exigency justifying a seizure.

column2: >3.2.1.2.1. Members shall inform their supervisor of their action to seize a device as soon as practical.

column4: If there are no exigent circumstances, but there is probable cause to believe the recording device or media contains evidence of or information concerning the commission of a Measure 11 offense, the member must contact the Multnomah County District Attorney&rsquo
column5: s Office and request it to issue a Subpoena Duces Tecum to seize the recording device or media.
Members should protect seized recording devices and media from remote access, such as through the use of a Faraday bag, to ensure legal viewing at a later time.&nbsp

column4: Viewing recordings or information contained on recording devices and media.

column5: Members may view recordings or information contained on seized devices and media if:

column4: The person recording consents to the viewing

The person recording possesses the recording device when arrested and is charged with a crime, and the member obtains a search warrant based on probable cause to view and duplicate the recording device&rsquo
Exigent circumstances exist requiring the immediate viewing, for example, to prevent death or serious physical injury to a person.&nbsp
The owner of any surrendered or seized device or media must be given a property receipt.&nbsp
All instances of viewing and/or seizing recordings should be documented in an appropriate police report.&nbsp
The recording device and its media should be held in police custody no longer than reasonably necessary for the police to obtain and execute a search warrant. &nbsp
column5: The recording device and its media should then be returned promptly to the device&rsquo
column6: s owner in accordance with Directive 660.10, Property and Evidence Procedures.&nbsp

0600 - Field Operations,Field Operations,735543,0630.61 Stolen Vehicles,ARB-PPB-0630.61,0630.61,2,,2020-07-06 17:24:57 UTC,2019-07-01 16:00:00 UTC,A,,"

630.61, Stolen Vehicles

column2: 164.138 Criminal Possession of a Rented or Leased Motor Vehicle

column1: <li>PPB Stolen Vehicle Election of Tow Options/Acknowledgment of Risk, Release From Liability and Hold Harmless Agreement Form&nbsp

1. It is the policy of the Portland Police Bureau to recover stolen vehicles taken through criminal activity and to refrain from exercising authority in situations involving vehicles taken in civil disputes.

column3: Upon sufficient proof of ownership and indications that the vehicle has been stolen, members shall complete a General Offense report.

In addition to completing the General Offense report, members shall also provide the PPB Stolen Vehicle Election of Tow Options/Acknowledgment of Risk, Release From Liability and Hold Harmless Agreement Form to the vehicle owner.&nbsp
column4: The owner must indicate whether they wish to have the recovered vehicle towed at their own expense or wish to have the vehicle left at the recovery location if they are unable to retrieve it in a timely manner.&nbsp

column3: Members shall explain to the owner that a failure to sign the form will result in the recovered vehicle being towed at the owner&rsquo

Upon taking a stolen vehicle report, members shall immediately call the Auto Records Desk to insure the stolen vehicle is immediately entered into the Law Enforcement Data Systems (LEDS) and the National Crime Information Center (NCIC).&nbsp
In order to accept a report on a stolen car, members shall conduct a preliminary investigation. &nbsp
column4: As part of that investigation, ownership must be established. &nbsp
column5: One or more of the following may establish proof of ownership:

column3: The complainant is the registered owner (per any Department of Motor Vehicles [DMV]), which is substantiated by personal identification. Telephone reports may be accepted if the complainant can satisfactorily assure the reporting officer that they are the registered owner via corroborating sources (i.e., familiarity with vehicle, type, make, names of other registered owners, and unique features of the vehicle [e.g., bumper stickers, pre-existing damage]).
The complainant provides documents from DMV indicating process of transfer of title.
The complainant has possession of a title signed for transfer.
The complainant has possession of a bill of sale from a licensed car dealer on letterhead, dated within the last 60 days.
The complainant has possession of a notarized bill of sale, for a private sale, dated within the last 60 days.

If the person reporting the vehicle as stolen had possession under a rental/ lease agreement, the reporting person must present the valid rental/lease agreement or telephone verification by the rental company.
The complainant is the owner of rented or leased vehicle and has completed the requirements set forth in ORS 164.138 (demand letter, 3-day waiting period, etc.).
In situations that do not meet the previous criteria, officers must contact a supervisor for authorization to accept a report of a stolen vehicle. &nbsp
column4: The person authorizing the report shall be documented in the report.&nbsp

column3: A stolen report will not be accepted under the following circumstances, which shall be deemed non-criminal and instead a civil disagreement:
Divorce completed with court ordered division of property.
Unmarried partner, domestic partner, roommate, family member or juvenile children of complainant, or those in a dating relationship. &nbsp
column4: Under these circumstances, a sergeant may authorize that a report be taken after at least 48 hours from the time of the initial notification to law enforcement.

column3: Vehicle is held by person(s) performing work on the vehicle (e.g., mechanic&rsquo
Vehicle in possession of co-signer on contract of purchase.
Vehicle taken from a tow company or mechanic&rsquo
column4: s garage, unless the owner is complainant.

column3: Vehicle purchased with a non-sufficient fund (NSF) check.
The vehicle is rented or leased, without fraud, and requirements set forth in ORS 164.138 have not been completed.
New or used car test drive unless 24 hours have elapsed from the time the vehicle should have been returned.
Stored vehicles, private property or storage facility, for which both parties cannot confirm theft.
The complainant is unwilling to prosecute.
The theft is a result of illegal activities such as drug transaction without mitigating circumstances (i.e., carjacking, armed robbery, etc.).
Commercial or private sale of vehicle, for which partial payment has been made.

column2: >1.4.2. A sergeant may authorize a report in cases falling into the categories above, in extraordinary circumstances to be documented in the report. &nbsp
column3: The report must include notation of the authorizing member.&nbsp
Fraud involving a title that has changed parties.
DMV requests to investigate a title to a vehicle that is being registered and is listed as stolen.

column2: >1.5.2. Officers shall complete a General Offense report if:

column3: The vehicle was obtained fraudulently, using a NSF, account closed, forged, altered, counterfeit check, security, money order or instrument.
The vehicle was obtained through identity theft. &nbsp
column4: The vehicle will be recorded as evidence with a full description including Vehicle Identification Number (VIN).

column2: >1.5.3. Under these circumstances, members shall only enter a vehicle as stolen in LEDS/NCIC with their immediate supervisor&rsquo

column3: Members shall not input vehicles as &ldquo
column5: in LEDS/NCIC unless there are other special circumstances (e.g., vehicle involved in a robbery or serious person crime).&nbsp

column3: All recovered vehicles must be confirmed by VIN and the LEDS/NCIC entry.&nbsp
Unless the recovered vehicle is a hazard, the member shall attempt to contact the vehicle owner via all methods listed prior to ordering a tow.&nbsp

If the owner indicated at the time of the initial report they wished to have the recovered vehicle towed at their own expense, the member shall have the vehicle towed if they are unable to contact the vehicle owner or if the vehicle owner is unable to respond in a timely fashion (a minimum of 60 minutes).&nbsp

If the owner indicated at the time of the initial report they wished to have the recovered vehicle left at the recovery location, the member shall attempt to contact the owner via all methods listed.&nbsp
column4: The member shall check the vehicle for apparent fresh damage or items of value, document the condition of the vehicle in their police report, and immediately clear the stolen vehicle entry out of LEDS/NCIC via Records Division.&nbsp

column3: If the original stolen vehicle report was taken by another law enforcement agency, the member shall attempt to contact the vehicle owner and have the vehicle towed if they are unable to contact the vehicle owner or if the vehicle owner is unable to respond in a timely fashion (a minimum of 60 minutes).&nbsp
The vehicle may be released to the registered owner or a designee following member verification of the owner&rsquo
column4: s information in the reporting system. &nbsp
column5: The releasing officer shall immediately notify the Records Division/Auto Records when a vehicle is towed or released in order to remove the vehicle from LEDS/NCIC stolen file.&nbsp
