0600 - Field Operations,Field Operations,738407,0640.20 Sexual Assault Kits and Sexual Assault Investigations,ARB-PPB-0640.20,0640.20,2,,2019-07-29 16:39:18 UTC,2019-07-31 07:00:00 UTC,A,,"

640.20, Sexual Assault Kits and Sexual Assault Investigations
<li>DIR 825.00, Domestic Violence, Arrests, and Restraining Orders<strong>&nbsp

column2: A sexual assault forensic evidence kit collected from a victim who either has not made a decision to participate in the prosecution of the perpetrator or the sexual assault, or has chosen not to participate in the prosecution of the perpetrator of the sexual assault.&nbsp

When a victim of a sexual assault does not want to report to law enforcement, but chooses to disclose their abuse to a medical provider who can perform a forensic medical exam to preserve evidence.&nbsp

column4: adult persons related by blood, marriage, or adoption
column5: persons who are cohabiting or who have cohabited with each other
column6: persons who have been involved in a sexually intimate relationship with each other within two years immediately preceding the filing by one of them of a petition to circuit court for relief

column2: Any person not listed as a family member, including neighbors, friends, teachers, and other temporary child custodians and strangers.&nbsp

Any unwanted sexual contact from an individual, by means of touching the sexual or other intimate parts of a person or causing such person to touch the sexual or other intimate parts of the actor for the purpose of arousing or gratifying the sexual desire of either party, is considered an offense under Oregon State laws.&nbsp
column3: The commission of or attempted commission of a sexual offense chargeable under State laws include rape, sodomy, unlawful sexual penetration, sexual abuse, and purchasing sex with a minor.&nbsp

column2: Volunteers from either a local non-profit organization specializing in serving victims of sexual assault or from the District Attorney&rsquo
column4: These individuals respond to police requests through the Bureau of Emergency Communication (BOEC) to stay with a victim through hospital evaluation and care while also providing support and advocacy as needed.<strong>&nbsp

column1: 1. In accordance with Oregon State law, the Portland Police Bureau (PPB) shall designate a point of contact to serve as both PPB&rsquo
column2: s Sexual Assault Kit (SAK) Program Coordinator and liaison to the Oregon State Police (OSP).&nbsp
column3: This individual serves as a bridge between the two organizations and will be a resource for victims of sexual assault seeking information on their particular cases.&nbsp
column4: PPB shall ensure that the contact information for the SAK Program Coordinator is communicated to local medical facilities and organizations that work with the Bureau to assist victims, thereby providing those affected by sexual assault with the knowledge on who to engage for further assistance.&nbsp

column1: 2. Contact with first responders is critical to a victim&rsquo
column2: s decision as to whether or not to move forward in the criminal justice system and to the victim&rsquo
column4: Although it is necessary for members to investigate the crime scene, potential evidence, and suspects, members must also be sensitive to the difficulty of the situation for the victim. &nbsp
column5: Bureau members are expected to use the following procedures when responding to a sexual assault.<strong>&nbsp

column3: If emergency medical treatment is required, members shall request ambulance transport for the victim to the nearest hospital or the hospital of their choice.&nbsp
Members shall ensure they advise victims of the following:

If a sexual assault occurred within the past 120 hours, members shall inform the victim that they have the option to have a forensic medical exam to collect evidence, also known as a sexual assault kit (SAK), for a criminal investigation at no cost to them. &nbsp
If the victim chooses to go to the hospital for an exam, members shall advise them not to eat or drink, bathe or change clothes prior to the examination, since evidence present on the victim&rsquo
column4: s body and/or clothing may be destroyed or contaminated.&nbsp
column5: Members shall also request through BOEC for a SAVA to respond to the hospital and if possible, members shall conduct an interview with the victim in the presence of the SAVA.

column3: If a member is present at the time that a SAK is collected and the victim has not received contact information for a SAK liaison from another source, the member shall provide the victim with contact information for the Bureau&rsquo
column4: s SAK Program Coordinator who is responsible for receiving all inquiries (telephonic or otherwise) regarding SAKs.

column3: For an incident older than 120 hours, a forensic exam is not necessary because DNA evidence deteriorates with time and may no longer be present. &nbsp
column4: Members shall inform the victim of this but also explain that they can still go to the hospital for a wellness exam at no cost to them.&nbsp

column3: Members shall call the Forensic Evidence Division (FED) so they can take photos of the victim and the scene.&nbsp
Members shall determine the location of the clothing worn by the victim during and/or immediately after the sexual assault. &nbsp
column4: If the victim is still wearing the same clothes worn during the assault, recommend the victim bring a complete change of clothing to the hospital due to possible seizure of the clothes.&nbsp
column5: If the victim is not wearing the same clothes worn during the assault, collect as evidence the clothes the victim wore during the assault if not yet laundered.&nbsp

column3: Members shall gather physical evidence in accordance with Section 4, Evidence Disposition.&nbsp
Members shall forward reports of sexual assault in which the victim and suspect are family or household members to the Domestic Violence Reduction Unit (DVRU).&nbsp
column4: The DVRU Supervisor may consult with the Sex Crimes Unit (SCU) Supervisor to determine if specific cases would be better investigated by SCU.&nbsp

column3: Members shall complete an appropriate police report submitted through their Responsibility Unit and forward a copy to the Detective Division prior to the end of shift.&nbsp

column1: 2. Detective Division Responsibilities for Sexual Assault Investigations.

column3: In the event detective contact is needed, responding member(s) shall inform their supervisor.&nbsp
column4: The supervisor shall make contact with the Detective Division who shall determine the appropriate response.

column3: An SCU Detective may be requested and assigned when the victim(s) are 14 years old and older and the perpetrator is a non-family member.
The suspect is in custody for:
Unlawful Sexual Penetration I and II.
Cases in which an individual 18 years old or older decides to report an offense that occurred when they were a juvenile shall be referred to SCU detectives.
A Child Abuse Team (CAT) Detective may be requested and assigned when the victim(s) are under 18 years old and the perpetrator is a family member.&nbsp
The suspect is in custody for:
Unlawful Sexual Penetration I and II.&nbsp
The victim is able to articulate a crime has been committed or the member is able to determine a crime was committed,
The crime is no more than 120 hours old,
The victim is willing to cooperate with an investigation, and
The nature or complexity of the crime requires a detective response.
A detective sergeant or shift sergeant may determine a detective response is necessary when circumstances do not fall within the above criteria.&nbsp

column4: s Responsibility Unit (RU) Manager shall determine which unit will investigate cases that involve both sexual assault and domestic violence.&nbsp

column3: The Detective Division shall investigate further and coordinate with the District Attorney&rsquo
The SAK Program Coordinator located in SCU shall receive all inquiries (telephonic or otherwise) from victims regarding their SAK.&nbsp
column4: This Bureau member shall also serve as a liaison between PPB and OSP, being responsible for coordinating and communicating information on a victim&rsquo

column3: Upon request by a victim, the SAK Program Coordinator may provide details regarding the victim&rsquo
column4: s personal SAK to include, but not limited to, the following information:

column3: Whether a DNA sample was obtained from the SAK and if so, whether or not there are matches to DNA profiles in state or federal databases.
The estimated date of destruction for the SAK.&nbsp

In the event that a victim makes an inquiry but providing the requested information interferes with the investigation or prosecution of a case, the SAK Program Coordinator shall not disclose details but rather, provide an explanation for why they cannot release the information.<em>&nbsp
The SAK Program Coordinator shall respond to a victim&rsquo
column4: s inquiry concerning their SAK as soon as practical, but no later than 30 days from the inquiry.&nbsp

column3: The SAK Program Coordinator shall document any request from a victim to have a designee access information on their behalf.&nbsp
column4: The SAK Program Coordinator shall inform the victim that written authorization must be provided to PPB to ensure that access is granted to the appropriate person.&nbsp

column3: When requested by a victim to either reclassify an untested non-anonymous kit to an anonymous kit or reclassify an untested anonymous kit as a non-anonymous kit, the SAK Program Coordinator shall notify OSP of the reclassification.
Upon receiving notification from a medical facility that a SAK has been collected, a sworn member shall retrieve the SAK within seven days.&nbsp
Members shall collect anonymous kits as well as SAKs at the request of outside agencies when a victim is reporting within Portland jurisdiction.&nbsp
column4: This is commonly referred to as a courtesy report.

column3: Upon retrieving a SAK, the member shall scan the kit bar code using the Sexual Assault Kit Tracking System (SAKTS) mobile app to ensure chain of custody.&nbsp

Once in possession of a SAK from the medical facility, members involved in investigating sexual assaults shall ensure evidence is appropriately packaged by the involved hospital, complete a Property/Evidence receipt, and transport the evidence to the Property and Evidence Room.
Clothing and other evidence with body fluids are considered biohazardous.&nbsp
column4: Members shall refer to Directive 660.10, Property and Evidence Procedures, for more information regarding proper delivery of these items. &nbsp
column5: Members should use the following recommended precautions when handling biohazardous evidence:

column3: Wet body fluids and dry blood: Rubber gloves, mask, and eye protection.
Dry body fluids and dry blood: Rubber gloves, and, if available, mask and eye protection.&nbsp
The Property and Evidence Division (PED) shall submit the SAK to OSP for forensic testing within 14 days from the time of receiving the SAK from a medical facility.&nbsp
column4: The SAK Program Coordinator shall provide OSP any information sufficient to allow OSP to prioritize testing.&nbsp

column3: PED shall not submit any anonymous kits to OSP for testing.&nbsp
PED shall retain all SAKs, including anonymous kits, for no less than 60 years after the SAK was collected.

0600 - Field Operations,Field Operations,741045,0630.26 Public Safety Support Specialist Program,ARB-PPB-0630.26,0630.26,2,,2019-09-03 18:27:02 UTC,2019-09-05 07:01:00 UTC,A,,"

630.26, Public Safety Support Specialist Program
<li>Training Division Standard Operating Procedure 3-8, Public Safety Support Specialist Program&nbsp

column2: A threat or overt act of an assault (through physical or verbal means), coupled with the present ability to carry out the threat or assault, which reasonably indicates that an assault or injury to any person is about to happen, unless intervention occurs.&nbsp
Non-sworn members who are authorized to assist sworn members in the performance of certain duties that do not require law enforcement authority.&nbsp
column3: Public Safety Support Specialists do not meet the statutory definition of &ldquo
column5: and are not Department of Public Safety Standards and Training (DPSST)-certified
column6: therefore, they are not law enforcement officials (i.e., sworn members).&nbsp

column2: A sworn member or a non-probationary Public Safety Support Specialist who is assigned to a probationary Public Safety Support Specialist and responsible for both monitoring and documenting their performance, and providing resources to assist in their training and development.&nbsp
s (PPB) Public Safety Support Specialists (PS3s) provide support to the Bureau&rsquo
column3: s sworn members in non-emergency, non-priority situations
column4: engage in community outreach with the public
column5: offer a visible, community-based police support function to enhance PPB&rsquo
column7: PS3s shall not replace other job classifications, although they may support such work if needed.&nbsp

column3: PS3s shall receive initial training as determined by the Training Division.&nbsp
column4: At a minimum, this training shall consist of the following:

column3: An introductory academy or comparable specialized training
Instruction with a mental health focus
A field training program with a PS3 Coach.&nbsp
PS3s shall complete a one year probationary period from the date of hire.&nbsp
PS3s shall have an assigned PS3 coach during their probationary period.&nbsp
PS3s shall receive ongoing training as determined by the Training Division.&nbsp

column1: 2. Public Safety Support Specialists Duties and Responsibilities.

column3: PS3s shall act in accordance with all applicable Bureau Directives, Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs), and City of Portland Human Resources Administrative Rules (HRARs).&nbsp
column4: They shall follow the lawful orders, commands, and instructions of sworn members.

column3: PS3s may utilize the Law Enforcement Data System (LEDS) and National Crime Information Center (NCIC) after completing appropriate training.
Depending on the assignment, under the supervision of a sworn police supervisor, PS3s may perform a combination of some or all of the following duties, and perform related duties as assigned.
Write police reports for non-emergency situations that do not require police officer authority, and do not involve potential evidence, suspects, or a crime scene.
Respond to non-injury traffic collisions to facilitate information exchange between involved parties
column4: coordinate tow services for disabled vehicles.

column3: Conduct follow-up on property crimes where there is no suspect information, either by phone or in person, with an emphasis on crime victims&rsquo
column4: rights and referrals to other City Bureaus.

column3: Process evidence or property, including writing reports and properly securing property.
Attend neighborhood meetings, community and/or public events. (This does not replace attendance at such events by sworn officers.)

Assist police officers in searching for missing persons such as elderly adults, medically fragile adults, or children when there is no reason to believe they are a threat to themselves or the community.
Assist with inventory and maintenance of PPB-issued equipment, excluding weapons and ammunition.
Assist drivers in stalled vehicles and summon other necessary assistance
column4: respond to pedestrians, bicyclists, and other community members in need of assistance.

column3: Broadcast and receive messages via police radio and Mobile Data Terminal (MDT)
column5: ask for assistance when appropriate due to incident type and scope.

column3: Assist with temporary street closures, detours and other public service duties identified by police supervisors.
Summon a police officer for situations they encounter in which enforcement action is necessary.&nbsp
PS3s shall be assigned to a precinct and work on an existing standard shift that mirror patrol schedules patrol precincts.&nbsp
column4: They shall report to the shift sergeant(s) while on duty.&nbsp

column3: Upon completion of the required probationary period and with the approval of their assigned shift sergeant, PS3s may have community members accompany them on a shift to observe their activities.&nbsp
PS3s taking any authorized action while on duty shall write and submit an appropriate report to cover the incident, in accordance with Directive 900.00, General Reporting Guidelines.
If a PS3 uses force while on duty, they shall immediately notify a supervisor and complete all force reporting requirements, in accordance with Directive 1010.00, Use of Force.&nbsp
Unless otherwise instructed by a supervisor, PS3s are not authorized to participate in or perform the following duties:
Calls for service involving contact or potential contact with a criminal suspect(s)
Any incident where it is likely there will be contact with a person in crisis (e.g., mental health, intoxication, drug-affected, etc.)
Custodial transports (i.e., suspects, detox, Peace Officer Hold [POH])
Emergency driving or any driving in violation of Oregon State traffic laws
Respond as cover for sworn members
Any call where a sergeant determines it is outside the scope of employment or duties of a PS3.&nbsp
PS3s shall not work undercover assignments.&nbsp

PS3s shall not use physical force, unless placed in a position where the force is in response to active aggression, and they must defend themselves or others in accordance with the standards set forth in Directive 1010.00, Use of Force, and Directive 315.30, Satisfactory Performance.&nbsp
If a PS3 is involved in a force incident, this force will be subject to Directive 1010.00, Use of Force, and must include a complete After Action review by the precinct supervisor.&nbsp
PS3s shall wear uniforms with patches and/or logos that are distinct from Bureau sworn member uniforms and identify them as Police Bureau members.&nbsp
PS3s may attend trainings and certain events out of uniform, as appropriate (e.g., trainings with business casual dress requirements, other special events with permission from a sergeant).&nbsp
PS3s shall not wear or be issued PPB badges.&nbsp
PS3s shall carry defensive equipment (i.e., aerosol restraint) as determined by the Training Division.
PS3s shall not be issued any of the following devices:
Any less lethal devices that operate on principles consistent with a firearm (e.g., less-lethal 40mm devices).
PS3s are prohibited from carrying any firearms or less-lethal devices described above in the performance of the normal course of their duties.&nbsp
The Bureau shall assign specialized vehicles designed for PS3s&rsquo
column5: PS3s are only authorized to operate marked PPB vehicles to accomplish a specific task (e.g., move a vehicle between precincts, reposition vehicles at a crime scene).&nbsp

column1: 5. Public Safety Support Specialist Coach Responsibilities.

column2: >5.1. All PS3 coaches shall have a demonstrable record of professional conduct and suitable work performance.

column3: Members who have been subject to disciplinary action based upon the use of force or mistreatment of individuals with mental illness within the three preceding years, or twice in the preceding five years, shall be prohibited from serving as PS3 coaches.&nbsp

column2: >5.2. PS3 coaches shall monitor and evaluate the performance of their assigned PS3s during the designated probationary period.&nbsp

column3: The precinct shift sergeant shall supervise the day to day activities of any assigned PS3s.
If the PS3 uses force (e.g., aerosol restraint deployment), the supervisor shall act in accordance with Directive 1010.00, Use of Force, when reviewing the incident.&nbsp
The Training Division shall administer the PS3 Program and maintain a program SOP.&nbsp
The Training Division Captain or a designee shall determine all PS3 Program-related training.&nbsp

0600 - Field Operations,Field Operations,750900,0640.18 Case Management,ARB-PPB-0640.18,0640.18,2,,2020-01-06 20:29:01 UTC,2020-01-06 20:21:00 UTC,A,,"

640.18 Case Management

column2: Police reports submitted by an initial officer that are determined by a supervisor or detective sergeant that an investigation is warranted are then assigned to a member by using the Record Management System (RMS).&nbsp
column3: Assigned cases will typically be identified as &ldquo
column9: (D) in the RMS until the disposition code is changed to a closure status.&nbsp

column2: Identifiers listed in the RMS to describe the status of a case.&nbsp
column3: Commonly used codes by members include inactive/suspended, unfounded, or one of the referral options.&nbsp

column2: For the purpose of this directive, a case that warrants further follow-up to identify a suspect(s) or locate evidence is assigned to a specific sworn member.&nbsp
column3: Misdemeanor investigations are generally conducted at the precinct level.&nbsp
column4: Felony crimes and aggregate misdemeanor crimes are reviewed by the appropriate investigative unit under the Investigations Branch, with the exception of stolen or recovered vehicles without suspect leads.&nbsp

column2: A central database of police reports, name records, and other report data.&nbsp
column3: Investigating members, detectives, and supervisors will use the RMS to document the progress of a case, track the status on each assigned case, and monitor all cases assigned for follow up.&nbsp

column1: 1. This directive establishes the procedures for Portland Police Bureau (PPB) members who use the Bureau&rsquo
column2: s Record Management System (RMS) to manage investigative cases.&nbsp
column3: Case management is a continuous and ongoing process that requires regular maintenance of information by investigating members and supervisors.&nbsp

column2: >1.1. On a weekly basis, members shall log into RMS to monitor assigned cases and identify any new cases assigned to them by their supervisor.&nbsp
>1.2. Members shall update case information in the RMS as an investigation progresses.&nbsp

>1.2.1. Members may use additional resources such as Microsoft Office applications to supplement the management of documentation (e.g., images, spreadsheets) through the course of their investigation.
>1.2.2. Investigative work using other resources must be added to the RMS in a timely manner.&nbsp
>1.3. Members shall review their assigned cases every 90 days and document changes and follow-up as needed.&nbsp
>1.4. Members shall input a closure status code at the conclusion or suspension of an investigation.&nbsp
column3: For suspended cases, members shall provide a brief text entry, clarifying the closure status.&nbsp

column2: >2.1. Supervisors shall use the RMS to track case progress in order to maintain uniformity and supervisory control regarding the assignment and closure of cases assigned for follow-up investigation.&nbsp
>2.2. Supervisors shall review incoming police reports that are routed to their case management queue and determine the appropriate course. &nbsp
column3: Supervisors shall determine whether to suspend further investigation of a case, assign an investigator to a case, or send the case to another responsibility unit (RU) for review.

column2: >2.2.1. Supervisors shall evaluate whether to assign a case to an investigator based on the following criteria which include, but are not limited to:
>2.2.1.4. Level of violence or severity of the crime (Measure 11),
>2.2.1.5. Presence of physical or electronic evidence, or
>2.2.1.6. Cooperation of the victim(s) and/or witness(es).
>2.2.2. If a supervisor determines that there is not enough information to assign a case to an investigator, they shall suspend the case in RMS using an appropriate closure status code.&nbsp
column3: When needed, supervisors who suspend a case shall document the reason for the closure.&nbsp

column2: >2.3. Supervisors shall ensure cases that are being actively investigated or reopened from a suspended status are identified in the RMS as &ldquo

column3: s assigned cases every 90 days for updates. Supervisors shall follow up on cases flagged as &ldquo
column5: in the RMS and assign more time on the case or cease further investigation.&nbsp

column1: 3. Responsibility Unit Manager or Designee Responsibilities.

column2: >3.1. The RU Manager may directly assign a case at their discretion.
>3.2. The RU Manager or their designee shall log into RMS every 180 days, at a minimum, to check case statuses.
>3.2.1. The RU Manager and any designee must have adequate permissions within the RMS.&nbsp
>3.3. The RU Manager of Detectives shall review case management queues and determine the threshold for overload and acceptable work load by unit.&nbsp

Any mental injury to a child which shall include only observable and substantial impairment of the child&rsquo

substance or to the unlawful manufacturing of a cannabinoid extract.&nbsp

adult persons related by blood, marriage, or adoption

column2: A physical injury which creates a substantial risk of death, or which causes serious and protected disfigurement, protracted impairment of health or protracted loss or impairment of function of any bodily organ.&nbsp

Any sexual contact, by means of touching the sexual or other intimate parts of a person or causing such person to touch the sexual or other intimate parts of the actor for the purpose of arousing or gratifying the sexual desire of either party, with a person who does not consent or who is incapable of consenting to a sexual act because of their age, mental status, or because they are physically helpless. &nbsp

column1: 1. Child abuse investigations are sensitive in nature.
column2: The Portland Police Bureau (PPB) recognizes the importance of providing confidential and compassionate service in a professional manner with due care and concern for the individuals affected. &nbsp
column3: In all instances, the protection of children shall be the highest priority.&nbsp

column1: 2. As part of a multi-disciplinary team (MDT) approach, all law enforcement agencies in Oregon are required to write a police report and notify the Department of Human Services (DHS), the District Attorney&rsquo
column2: s Office, and the Child Abuse Response and Evaluation Services-Northwest (CARES-NW) on cases involving child abuse, even if the allegations are determined to be unfounded.&nbsp
column3: Therefore, PPB collaborates with other service providers including the Department of Human Services (DHS) child protective services, school officials, and local health and mental health departments to develop specific procedures and guidelines for investigating cases of child abuse.<strong>&nbsp
Responding to cases of physical injury.
Members who observe a child who has suffered a suspicious physical injury shall ensure that a designated medical professional conducts a medical assessment within 48 hours.&nbsp
column4: Members shall do any of the following to fulfill this requirement:

column3: Contact CARES-NW via phone or email&nbsp
column4: to arrange for a medical assessment, or

column3: Advise the responding detective of the child&rsquo
column4: s suspicious physical injury and need for a medical assessment within 48 hours, or

column3: In the absence of a responding detective, advise the DHS Hotline for child abuse of the child&rsquo
column4: s suspicious physical injury and the need for a medical assessment within 48 hours.

column3: If the child requires emergency medical treatment or evaluation, the member shall request ambulance transportation to the nearest hospital or hospital of family choice. &nbsp
column4: If the child needs non-emergency medical treatment, the member may transport the child to a medical facility, preferably with another member, if feasible.

column3: Members facilitating the transportation of a child to a hospital for treatment of a serious physical injury shall immediately notify their supervisor who will contact a CAT supervisor or Detective supervisor.&nbsp
Responding to cases of child sexual abuse.
Members shall request through their supervisors for the Detective Division (Detectives) Child Abuse Team (CAT) to respond in cases where:
A child has been sexually assaulted within 120 hours.
The victim is under 14 years of age and the suspect is a non-family member.
The victim is under 18 years of age and the suspect is a family member.

Members who have reasonable cause to believe that a child is a victim of sexual abuse and that physical evidence of the abuse is likely to be destroyed shall seek a physical examination pursuant to Directive 640.20, Sexual Assault Kits and Sexual Assault Investigations. &nbsp

The responding member shall coordinate the medical treatment, physical examination, and sexual assault kit (SAK) of the child unless they are relieved of this requirement by another member or detective.&nbsp
column4: The member shall document in their report the time and individual who assumed responsibility of the case.&nbsp

column3: In the event that a child under 12 years of age&nbsp
column4: refuses to have an examination conducted and the child&rsquo
column5: s parent or guardian refuses to allow medical evaluation, the member shall take the child into protective custody.&nbsp
column6: Members shall contact Detectives and DHS for assistance.

column3: Members may facilitate transportation or transport a child to the preferred children&rsquo
column5: s Hospital at Emanuel Medical Center. &nbsp
column6: On weekdays, members shall contact a CAT supervisor to arrange an emergency examination at the CARES-NW Program at Randall Children&rsquo

column3: Members shall request through the Bureau of Emergency Communications (BOEC) for a Sexual Assault Victim Advocate (SAVA) to respond to the appropriate hospital.
In the best interest of the children, it is preferable for all children to be interviewed by CARES-NW or a similar Child Forensic Interview Center.&nbsp
column4: For reporting purposes, members shall thoroughly interview the person(s) to whom the child disclosed the abuse.

column3: Members shall attempt to minimize the amount of interviews conducted with child abuse victims.&nbsp
column4: Members not specifically trained in child interview techniques shall refrain from interviewing children under the age of 10.

column3: For cases of physical abuse, if necessary, members may interview the child (if they are able to speak) using non-leading questions.
Members may interview children over the age of 10, but only to the extent necessary to establish a criminal allegation.&nbsp
Members shall not interview children who are 10 years of age or younger.&nbsp
column4: These cases shall be referred to CARES-NW, the assigned DHS personnel, or a CAT detective. &nbsp

column3: If a sexual crime occurred within 120 hours, a member may conduct a short interview with the child to establish if the child needs an immediate medical examination.
If the child (or other children) is at risk by a perpetrator still within the home, a member may conduct a brief interview with the child to establish the need for protective custody.&nbsp
Sworn members involved in a case of child abuse shall coordinate efforts with DHS workers to secure photographic evidence of abuse.
Pursuant to Oregon law, any person conducting a child abuse investigation who observes a child who has suffered suspicious physical injury shall immediately photograph the injuries.&nbsp
column4: Anogenital injuries may only be photographed by a medical provider, but even these injuries must be photographed immediately.

column3: Members may contact CARES-NW directly via email and provide information regarding a child abuse case (i.e., case number, child&rsquo
column4: s name and birth date, and photographic evidence) as a method of complying with Karly&rsquo

column3: Any photographic evidence shall be emailed to CARES-NW prior to uploading into the Digital Image and Management System (DIMS).
Requesting criminalists from the participating agency or Forensics to respond to the scene.
Sworn members shall ensure submitted photographs accurately represent size and scope of injuries with the use of a scale reference.
If a child is taken into protective custody, sworn members who take photographs of the child&rsquo
column4: s injuries shall first email photographs to CARES-NW and then upload the images into the Digital Image Management System (DIMS) in accordance with Directive 640.02, Photography and Digital Imaging.

column3: Members who encounter cases of child neglect shall document unhealthy environments or unsafe conditions through photographs to serve as important photographic evidence for criminal prosecution and juvenile court purposes.&nbsp
Members shall observe the child and parent in the environment and document any of the following through photographs:
If the parent(s) displays needle marks on their body
Lack of food or expired dates on food products
Uninhabitable or other unsafe conditions (e.g., broken windows, leaking roof).&nbsp
Management of sexual exploitation photographic evidence.
Allegations of sexual exploitation involving visual recordings of sexual conduct of children have the potential to expand the investigation to a complex multi-jurisdictional investigation. &nbsp
column4: Members responding to these calls shall:

column3: Determine the media (printed, electronic, film, video tape, etc.) on which the visual recordings of sexual conduct of children exist.
Prohibit any person from further viewing or distributing the visual recordings of sexual conduct of children.&nbsp
column4: This includes having any of the recordings duplicated or otherwise sent to the member&rsquo

column3: Members shall inform individuals who have evidence on their electronic devices (i.e., smartphones, tablets, computers) to not delete the recordings or images until they can be extracted by FED or an appropriate agency.
Lawfully secure items of potential evidentiary value by seizing them as evidence under a warrant consent or other exceptions to the warrant requirement.&nbsp
column4: Extreme care should be taken when seizing computers and other electronic devices/media on which the recordings are stored to ensure the evidence is preserved.

column3: Interview and obtain clear and detailed statements from witnesses who observed the recordings regarding the sexual conduct depicted in the visual recordings.
Notify the CAT supervisor and advise them of the circumstances in order to determine whether or not a detective will respond to coordinate the investigation.&nbsp
Responding to child abuse calls on public school property.

If the initial response and investigation is conducted on public school premises, the school administrator will first be notified by a responding member, unless the administrator is the subject of the investigation.&nbsp
column4: According to state law, a designated school staff member&rsquo
column5: s presence for an interview is not required, therefore, the Bureau member shall use their judgment on whether to include them.&nbsp

column3: A child may be taken into protective custody when:
A child under 10 years of age is left without supervision.

column4: s conditions or surroundings reasonably appear to jeopardize the child&rsquo

column3: If a child is taken into protective custody, the member shall make reasonable efforts to notify the parents immediately, regardless of the time of day. Notification may be in person, by telephone, or in email.&nbsp
Name of the child taken into custody
Explanation as to why the child was taken into custody

column4: s location placement (i.e., hospital, shelter home, Juvenile Detention Hall [JDH], etc.)

column3: Scheduling information for Juvenile Court proceedings
The telephone number of the DHS Hotline for child abuse.
A CAT supervisor may waive this notification if they determine that immediate notification of a parent may compromise the investigation or endanger other children.
Under no circumstances shall the member inform an individual, including a parent, of the location of a foster/shelter care home, nor shall they disclose the location in their report.
If a member intervenes and relocates a child (i.e., moves them to or from a shelter care, writes a medical hold, or places them with a relative or friend), they shall do the following:
Write General Offense (GO) and Arrest Booking reports
Notify the DHS Hotline for child abuse
Deliver via in-person or fax copies of police reports to Juvenile Court intake as soon as practical, but no later than the end of shift.
If an adult caretaker is arrested for child abuse, the arresting member shall call the DHS Hotline for child abuse, even if the child is not taken into protective custody.&nbsp
The member shall take a child into protective custody when:
The child is in immediate danger if not taken into protective custody.

There is a threat that abuse will occur if the child is not removed from the home (i.e., the child has been the victim of sexual molestation by a family member and that family member is still in the home, likely to return to the home or the other members of the family are not supportive of the victim).
There are no other alternative resources such as a relative to care for the child.
If a DHS social worker is present at the location of the call, the member may allow the representative to take custody of the child.&nbsp
column4: In other circumstances, the member shall transport the child to a confidential destination as directed by DHS or the Juvenile Intake Unit.&nbsp

column3: The responding member is responsible for the criminal investigation even when a DHS worker is present.&nbsp
For cases where probable cause exists for criminal mistreatment 1 or misdemeanor assault on a child physical abuse case, members shall contact Detectives or a CAT supervisor
column4: however, if no detective is available or the CAT supervisor advises the member to handle the case, the member shall:

column3: Advise the suspect of their Miranda rights

column4: s response to either waive their rights or invoke their right to remain silent.

column3: Interview the suspect if they waive their rights.

column4: s statements in their police report

column3: Ensure all reports are attached along with the suspect&rsquo
column4: s RegJIN/LEDS printout in a case envelope correspondence

column3: Email photographs to CARES-NW and then upload the images into DIMS in accordance with Directive 640.02, Photography and Digital Imaging.&nbsp
column4: Notify the Deputy District Attorney (DDA) once the photographs are in DIMS for their review.

column5: is appropriately displayed in a case envelope correspondence.&nbsp

column3: Members shall write a police report for all cases of reported physical or sexual child abuse, even if the allegations appear unfounded.&nbsp
column4: Under no circumstances shall members provide BOEC a coded radio disposition in lieu of writing a report.

column3: Members shall write a GO report if they determine that a crime has been committed.
Members shall describe and document all injuries, no matter how minor, in the GO report.
Members shall provide description details such as listing the location of injuries on the child&rsquo
column5: describing each injury by size, shape and color
column6: and identifying the object that caused the injury if known.

column3: Members shall write a GO report for calls they determine to be unfounded.
Members shall write a police report when dispatched to cover DHS.&nbsp
column4: If multiple members respond to assist DHS, only one police report is necessary.

column3: Members shall write GO and Arrest Booking reports when:

column4: s location is changed by a member&rsquo
column5: s intervention (i.e., shelter care, medical hold, or placed with a relative, friend or DHS)

column3: A child is taken from a current custodian and given to another person, including a DHS social worker.
Members shall write a courtesy report for outside agencies for any of the following circumstances:
When the location of occurrence is outside Portland Police jurisdiction.
An outside agency advises they will not respond.
An outside agency requests a courtesy report.
Members shall not disclose the location of any shelter home in any report. &nbsp
column4: This is confidential information and may only be obtained from DHS.

column3: Members who receive a report from an individual 18 years or older reporting an offense that occurred when they were a juvenile, regardless of how much time has elapsed since, shall write a report and, if needed, make referrals.&nbsp
Members shall notify DHS of all suspected child abuse cases, unless the call originated from the DHS Hotline for child abuse. &nbsp
column4: Members shall indicate the time of notification at the beginning of a police report.&nbsp
column5: Members may also notify DHS in cases where a child witnesses domestic violence.&nbsp

column3: Supervisors shall review and/or monitor child abuse investigations for completeness by ensuring that the following are conducted: &nbsp
Verifying notification to DHS (required for protective custody or suspected child abuse initially discovered by members).
Verifying written reports for all child abuse calls, including those unfounded.
If a suspect is arrested, ensuring reports and photographs are forwarded to CAT Detectives as soon as practical.
Ensuring notification of a CAT supervisor if a child is sexually assaulted within 120 hours, or seriously injured and requires hospitalization.&nbsp
When Detectives are unable to respond and investigate, Detectives shall provide advice in response to members&rsquo
CAT will maintain a 24-hr on-call supervisor who shall provide immediate assistance and advice on child victim cases.&nbsp
column4: CAT may respond after hours and on weekends upon approval from a CAT supervisor.&nbsp

column3: A CAT Detective may be requested and assigned when the victim(s) are under 18 years of age and the perpetrator is a family member who is taken into custody for Rape I, Sodomy I, Sex Abuse I, or Unlawful Sexual Penetration I and II.&nbsp
Detectives shall respond to the appropriate hospital when:
A child has been sexually assaulted within the last 120 hours and there is likelihood of obtaining evidence through a SAK.
A child is hospitalized due to a suspicious serious physical injury.&nbsp
CAT shall receive and review copies of all child abuse reports. &nbsp
column4: A CAT supervisor may staff such reports with the DA and/or DHS representatives of the MDT in order to determine whether to assign a case for investigative follow-up or to refer the matter to DHS.&nbsp

column3: Criminalists shall respond to the location of a Measure 11 crime and take photographs of any visible injuries present on a child.&nbsp
When requested, Criminalists shall consult with the investigating member to determine what types of photographs are needed, where on a victim&rsquo
column4: s body to photograph, and the best location to take photographs.&nbsp

column3: Records will provide copies of all child abuse reports, founded and unfounded, to Department of Human Services (DHS), per ORS 419A.255 Maintenance

column1: 6. Notification of Child Abuse through BOEC or the Bureau&rsquo

column3: DHS may be the first to receive information on a child abuse case.&nbsp
column4: In these cases, DHS will determine if police response is necessary and will contact BOEC to dispatch a sworn member to respond to the call.&nbsp

column3: Incidents of child sexual abuse may be coordinated between DHS and the Bureau&rsquo
column4: s Operations Support Unit (OSU), however, OSU may take the report only under the following conditions:

column3: The child is currently safe and away from the perpetrator and the incident is being reported 120 hours after occurrence.
The caller is reluctant to make a direct report to a uniform member.
The caller is out of the area and their local law enforcement agency will not take a courtesy report regarding an incident that occurred within Portland.&nbsp

0600 - Field Operations,Field Operations,753448,0630.05 Vehicle Interventions and Pursuits,ARB-PPB-0630.05,0630.05,2,,2020-02-07 17:09:29 UTC,2020-02-09 08:01:00 UTC,A,,"

630.05 Vehicle Interventions and Pursuits
<li>DIR 1010.10, Deadly Force and In-Custody Death Reporting and Investigation&nbsp
Boxing In: A coordinated tactic of making contact between police vehicles and a suspect&rsquo
column3: vehicle to stop or prevent the start of a pursuit.&nbsp

column1: Marked Unit: An emergency police vehicle equipped with overhead lights.
Pursuit: An active, deliberate attempt by one or more members to apprehend one or more
column2: occupants of another moving vehicle, when it is reasonably apparent that the driver of that vehicle is aware of that attempt and is resisting apprehension by increasing speed, disobeying traffic laws, or attempting to elude the officer through evasive maneuvers or tactics.&nbsp

column1: Pursuit Intervention Technique (PIT): A driving technique designed to stop a fleeing
column2: motorist safely and quickly by making contact with the fleeing car at a specific point on the vehicle, which throws the car into a spin and brings it to a stop.&nbsp

column1: Ramming: The use of an emergency (police) vehicle, other than in a pursuit intervention
column2: technique or boxing in maneuver, to purposely cause contact with another vehicle in order to disable the vehicle.&nbsp

column1: Stop/Spike Strips: Devices used to deflate tires in a controlled fashion.
Vehicle: For purposes of this Directive, a vehicle is a motorized vehicle.
Vehicle Intervention Strategies: Tactics which may be used to stop or reduce the speed of a
column2: fleeing vehicle in an attempt to reduce safety risks posed to the community, the suspect, and members (e.g. barricading, boxing in, pursuit intervention technique, ramming, stop/spike strips).

column1: 1. The Bureau recognizes that vehicle pursuits are dynamic and rapidly evolving in nature and, as a result, have inherent safety risks. Therefore, members are expected to be able to articulate their decision-making with regard to pursuits, and for engaging in and/or continuing a pursuit. The choice to engage in and/or continue a pursuit shall be objectively reasonable under the totality of circumstances.
2. Members shall be trained in pursuit management. In an effort to uphold the Bureau&rsquo
column2: s commitment to protecting human life and property, members must balance the safety risks posed to the community against the benefit of capture before initiating and while continuing the pursuit.

column3: Members shall only initiate a pursuit of a suspect fleeing in a vehicle when there is reasonable suspicion to believe the suspect committed a felony person crime or where the suspect&rsquo
column4: s driving conduct, prior to the initiation of a stop, displays a willful disregard for the safety of others that reasonably places the public in immediate danger of serious bodily harm or death.&nbsp

column3: Members shall not engage in a pursuit under the following circumstances:

column4: s identity is known and the suspect can be apprehended at a future time, and if the suspect&rsquo
column5: s driving behavior, prior to the initiation of a stop, does not place the public in immediate danger of serious bodily harm or death.

column3: Police vehicles carrying suspects, complainants or witnesses shall not become involved in pursuits.
Cadets shall not become involved in pursuits.&nbsp
Members shall disengage from a pursuit under the following circumstances:

If the member is driving any vehicle other than a four-wheeled pursuit-rated marked unit when a pursuit is initiated, that member shall disengage primary pursuit when a four-wheeled pursuit-rated marked unit is in position to assume the pursuit.&nbsp
column4: The disengaging unit may follow at a safe distance until the conclusion of the pursuit.

column3: Police vehicles carrying passengers other than members, including ride-alongs, chaplains or cadets, shall disengage primary pursuit when a four-wheeled pursuit- rated marked unit is in position to assume the pursuit.
The pursuit has entered another jurisdiction, another agency has taken over the primary role in the pursuit, and the other agency has adequate cover present.

If a collision occurs as a result of the pursuit that is reasonably likely to require immediate medical assistance and more than one police vehicle is in pursuit, at least one pursuing member shall disengage from the pursuit and render appropriate aid while the other members continue pursuit. If only one police vehicle is in pursuit and a collision occurs as a result of the pursuit that is reasonably likely to require immediate medical assistance, but the benefit of capture outweighs disengagement, the pursuing member must call for immediate backup to render appropriate aid
column4: the involved member may continue the pursuit.

column3: For minor accidents not requiring immediate medical assistance, supporting members who are not engaged in the pursuit shall respond to the scene of the accident.
If a member is involved in a collision, they will immediately broadcast that information.&nbsp

When a member initiates a pursuit that they reasonably believe constitutes an extraordinary circumstance, the member shall immediately notify their supervisor of the pursuit and must receive permission to continue the pursuit.&nbsp

The below factors should be taken into consideration before deciding to initiate a pursuit, and these factors should be reassessed on an ongoing basis in deciding to continue or reengage in a pursuit. Members must be able to articulate reasons why the benefit of capture outweighs the safety risks posed to the community in the pursuit. Members must terminate a pursuit when the safety risks posed to the community clearly outweigh the benefit of capture. Key factors include:
The seriousness of the offense committed, and the risk the suspect(s) poses to the community.

column4: s driving behavior and vehicle condition, as well as the presence of passengers in the fleeing vehicle.
s knowledge of the area(s), proximity of cover and feasibility of implementing pursuit intervention strategies.

column3: The type of area, volume and presence of other vehicles and/or pedestrian traffic, and environmental and visibility conditions.

Only a maximum of three units shall engage in a pursuit with lights and sirens continuously activated. Upon initiation, at least one member in the pursuit shall frequently broadcast pertinent information (e.g. location, speed, direction, conditions, requests for specific interventions, etc.). The primary unit shall immediately notify the Bureau of Emergency Communications (BOEC) of the reasons for the pursuit and stay involved in some capacity until termination.

Exceptions to the three unit maximum may be authorized by a supervisor under very limited circumstances and only when an unusually dangerous situation dictates (e.g. multiple dangerous suspects, shots fired, armed robbery, etc.). Supervisory approval for additional pursuit vehicles must be authorized by voice over the air.
The decision to attempt to use a pursuit intervention technique maneuver will not alone be a justification for a fourth unit.&nbsp
The managing supervisor will announce their role over the radio, declare if the pursuit is authorized to continue, and respond to the area of the pursuit
column4: supervisors involved in the pursuit shall not assume management responsibilities.&nbsp

column3: Involved members and the supervisor should remain on the initial talk group (precinct dispatch net).&nbsp

Other members/units in the general vicinity of the pursuit who are not directly involved may proceed with caution to a position that would assist in perimeter support or to deploy stop/spike sticks.&nbsp

When feasible, the Air Support Unit will become the primary unit in a pursuit. The ground units will continue at a safe distance and at a reduced speed to respond and take control at the conclusion of the pursuit. The managing supervisor will maintain overall control of the pursuit and potential use of intervention strategies.&nbsp
Members may only employ pursuit intervention strategies that are Bureau approved and that they have been trained to use.
Members may use the pursuit intervention strategies listed below with lights/siren warnings when it is objectively reasonable to do so under the totality of the circumstances.&nbsp
When feasible, it is the supervisor&rsquo
column4: s responsibility to ensure pursuit intervention strategies are planned and deployed as soon as practical.&nbsp

column3: Members should, if time and circumstances permit, continually broadcast their intentions and actions as they use pursuit intervention strategies.&nbsp
Members may use the following Bureau-approved strategies. Unless otherwise noted, these strategies shall implicate force.

Boxing In: This tactic may be employed preemptively, meaning without lights/siren warnings, if a pursuit of the subject vehicle would be permitted under Section 1.1. of this directive. This tactic may also be employed preemptively in a static environment (e.g., the driver appears incapacitated or unconscious
column4: the subject vehicle is stationary in a parking lot) if the benefit gained outweighs the inherent risks of the maneuver. Finally, this tactic may be employed preemptively in a dynamic environment (e.g., the subject vehicle is temporarily stopped at a traffic control device) when there is probable cause to arrest a suspect in a vehicle and the totality of the circumstances indicates the suspect will attempt to avoid detention and arrest, or when the suspect&rsquo
column5: s driving behavior displays a willful disregard for the safety of others which reasonably places the public in immediate danger of serious bodily harm or death.&nbsp
column6: As described in Directive 1010.00, Use of Force, boxing in will be investigated as a Category IV use of force, if conducted at speeds at or below 20 miles per hour in conjunction with training. If the tactic is conducted at speeds above 20 miles per hour, the intent and manner in which the technique is used shall be considered to determine the appropriate category of force, as described in Directive 1010.00, Use of Force. Members are required to provide substantial justification under these circumstances, and supervisors have the discretion to elevate the category of the force investigation.

column3: Pursuit Intervention Technique: This tactic shall not be used on two-wheeled vehicles, passenger-occupied buses, and vehicles transporting hazardous materials. This tactic may be employed preemptively, meaning without lights/siren warnings, when there is probable cause to arrest a suspect in a vehicle and the totality of the circumstances indicates the suspect will attempt to avoid detention and arrest, or when the suspect&rsquo
column4: s driving behavior displays a willful disregard for the safety of others which reasonably places the public in immediate danger of serious bodily harm or death.&nbsp
column5: As described in Directive 1010.00, Use of Force, the PIT maneuver will be investigated as a Category III use of force, if conducted at speeds at or below 45 miles per hour in conjunction with training. If the tactic is conducted at speeds above 45 miles per hour, the intent and manner in which the technique is used shall be considered to determine the appropriate category of force, as described in Directive 1010.00, Use of Force. Members are required to provide substantial justification under these circumstances, and supervisors have the discretion to elevate the category of the force investigation.

column3: Ramming: Members should only employ this tactic in extraordinary circumstances. Any use of ramming requires substantial justification. As described in Directive 1010.00, Use of Force, ramming will be reviewed as a Category II use of force
column4: however, supervisors have the discretion to elevate the category of the force investigation. The intent and manner in which the technique is used shall be considered when making the determination to elevate the investigation.

column3: Stop/Spike Strips: This tactic is not considered force.
For pursuits coming into the Bureau&rsquo
column4: s jurisdiction from another jurisdiction, the managing supervisor will determine whether members will become involved in the pursuit. If the supervisor determines that the Bureau will assist in the pursuit, members may only engage in the pursuit consistent with this policy, regardless of the policies of the originating jurisdiction.&nbsp

column3: For pursuits beginning in Bureau jurisdiction but leaving from this jurisdiction, it is the responsibility of a member of the primary pursuing unit to: 1) inform the receiving jurisdiction of the conditions giving rise to the pursuit and the actions taken during the pursuit
column4: and 2) request assistance from the receiving jurisdiction. If the receiving jurisdiction agrees to assume primary control of the pursuit, once that transfer occurs, the Bureau will only continue the pursuit in a supporting role. If the receiving agency elects to terminate the pursuit while in that jurisdiction, PPB members will also terminate the pursuit.&nbsp

column3: Supervisors shall manage notification and direct control of pursuits that either extend into or are received from other jurisdictions, including the State of Washington.&nbsp

Members must terminate a pursuit when the safety risks posed to the community clearly outweigh the benefit of capturing the suspect. Termination may be called by any sworn member, whether involved in the pursuit or not. Members will terminate a pursuit when ordered to do so by any supervisor. Members will terminate a pursuit that travels into the State of Washington, unless the underlying offense is a violent person-to-person felony.&nbsp

Once a pursuit is terminated, involved members shall verbally acknowledge the termination over the radio, disengage and stop following the suspect vehicle. If involved in the pursuit, the Air Support Unit may continue to monitor the fleeing vehicle, but reengagement by ground units is limited by Section 7 of this Directive.&nbsp
Per Directive 310.20, Retaliation Prohibited, members shall not retaliate against involved members regarding the decision to terminate a pursuit.&nbsp

Members shall refer concerned property owner(s) whose property may have been damaged during a pursuit to the City of Portland's Risk Management Office, in accordance with Directive 220.40, Lawsuits and Claims.&nbsp

After termination, a member may reengage a pursuit of the suspect vehicle only if the member is able to articulate new reasons why the benefit of capture outweighs the safety risks posed to the community as a consequence of the pursuit (See Section 1, Pursuit Authorization and Section 2, Pursuit Balancing Factors).&nbsp

Involved members shall complete an appropriate police report detailing the pursuit in accordance with directives, and supervisors will complete any required force investigations in accordance with Directive 1010.00, Use of Force, or Directive 905.00, Non-Force After Action Reports. The intervention strategies detailed above when used on a subject&rsquo
column4: s vehicle are not accidents, and thus do not require accident related investigation and reporting.&nbsp

column3: In managing a pursuit, supervisors shall:
Determine if the pursuit is prohibited.
Continually balance the safety risks posed to the community against the benefit of capture in managing the pursuit.
Authorize and direct additional units to engage in a pursuit.
Ensure radio communication between all applicable parties.
Devise, approve and direct appropriate pursuit intervention strategies to end a pursuit as quickly as possible, so as to avoid or mitigate safety risks.
Manage notification and direct control of pursuits that either extend into or are received from other jurisdictions.

Order the pursuit be terminated when necessary (e.g., members are not adequately broadcasting updates, intervention strategies are not being planned or implemented, the safety risks posed to the community clearly outweigh the benefit of capture).
If ordering termination of a pursuit, verify with the involved member(s) their location at the time of the pursuit termination and document that location in the After Action Report.
Ensure reports are completed in accordance with directives.

Conduct a debriefing with all involved members. The debrief should include an overview of the pursuit and, when applicable, a discussion of any vehicle intervention strategies employed. Confirm that the debrief occurred in the After Action Report.

Complete an after action review and follow reporting requirements based on the category of force outlined in Direction 1010.00, Use of Force, and determine whether higher scrutiny is warranted based on the speed at which the vehicle intervention strategy was used pursuant to Section 4.4.
If no force is used, supervisors shall conduct a pursuit after action investigation pursuant to Directive 905.00, Non-Force After Action Reports.&nbsp
The Assistant Chief of Operations, or designee, shall prepare an annual report analyzing Police Bureau pursuits.&nbsp
Command staff shall review the annual report, discuss trends, identify gaps, and direct necessary policy and training updates in accordance with Directive 1500.00, Training.&nbsp

0700 - Emergencies / Disturbances,Emergencies / Disturbances,529207,0740.00 Explosive Device Incidents and EDU,ARB-PPB-0740.00,0740.00,2,,2019-07-09 18:23:40 UTC,2015-05-04 19:54:00 UTC,A,,"

740.00

The Bureau will immediately respond on calls of bomb threats and suspected explosive devices using the following procedures in order to protect the lives of citizens, protect the lives of members and protect property.
Major post-blast: A blast scene where there is injury and/or major property damage. Major post-blast scenes will be treated as a major crime scene.
Minor post-blast: A blast scene where there is only slight damage to property, (i.e., vandalism by explosive).

column2: Any member who receives information pertaining to a bomb threat will immediately notify the Bureau of Emergency Communications (BOEC) and a supervisor. If the member receiving the threat is in the building or location that is the target of the threat, communication will be by landline telephone, as radio broadcasts may interfere with explosive devices.
If possible, members will obtain the following information:

column3: The specific address and/or building location or name, floor, room number and location in the room the device has been placed.

column2: The type of bomb, its physical description and/or container.
The time the device will detonate.
The reason the device was placed (motivation).
The individual or group claiming responsibility.

BOEC will dispatch, by radio, a district car and detail sergeant or other supervisor to the location of the threat. BOEC will advise the nature of the call using appropriate radio codes (33B). In all calls involving bomb threats, a supervisor will respond to the scene.
Responders will use only hand-held radios within 100 feet of these calls (one block). Turn off all other devices (car radio, MDC, and cellular phones
column3: pagers that receive only are okay).

column2: If a device has been located, do not transmit within 100 feet or until told to do so by an Explosive Disposal Unit (EDU) member.

column3: If members are there in response to a bomb threat, turn off pack set until the immediate area has been searched. Never search an area with the radio on.
If you are in a high-rise structure, move up or down at least two floors from the target floor to an exterior wall by a window before transmitting.

column2: Members and supervisors will assist the person in charge of the targeted location in evaluating the bomb threat for validity and need for further action. Some of the factors to consider are specifics of the threat, nature of targeted location, time of detonation, physical access to the site, and current events at the location.

column3: The person in charge of the targeted location will have the responsibility to determine if a search is to be conducted.

column2: Members will assist in the organization and search of a building/premise if requested.

column3: Members will complete a written report detailing the threat and subsequent police actions. If information supports an investigation, the report will be forwarded to Detective Division Arson Detail for follow-up.

column2: If a suspected or actual explosive device is located, members will clear the immediate and adjacent areas. Members should move at least 100 feet from the suspected device before turning on any radio communication equipment (hand-held radio, car radio, cell phone, etc.) and notifying BOEC. Hand-held radios generate less radio energy, therefore they should be used for all on-scene communications.
Members will not touch or move any suspected device.
Once an area is clear of civilians, members should retreat to an area of substantial cover.

column3: EDU will assume command of the scene upon their arrival and until the area is declared safe to enter.

When a threat is received by any facility, building and/or premise, public or private, the decision to evacuate is the responsibility of the person in charge of that facility, building or premises. In multi-tenant buildings where an evacuation has been undertaken, members will ensure all tenants are aware an evacuation is occurring.
In the event a suspect device is found, the ranking member on the scene, or EDU member, will secure the area and start an evacuation of the immediate and adjacent areas.

Do not route evacuating personnel by or near a suspected explosive device. Keep all persons away from glass windows and doors. Once civilians have been moved away from the suspected device(s), the ranking member will also ensure public safety personnel have moved to a location that provides substantial hard cover while allowing members to keep a secure perimeter.

Minor post-blasts that involve slight damage may be handled by the assigned responding officer following a telephone conversation with EDU (i.e., small explosions by plastic bottle bombs or fireworks). All pipe bomb blasts will be investigated by EDU in conjunction with a fire investigator.

Where there is injury and/or major property damage, members will treat this as a major crime scene. Because of the possibility of a secondary explosion, members will ensure that once the injured person(s) is removed, all public safety personnel move away from the blast scene to a location that provides substantial hard cover. EDU and the Arson detective will be notified immediately.

column2: EDU will assume command of the scene on their arrival and until the area is declared safe to enter. They will provide technical assistance to the Detective Division (Detectives) in processing the scene.
Detectives will be responsible for the follow-up investigation.

Request that BOEC activate EDU. Members should be prepared to give BOEC a brief description of the suspected device and location of a safe staging area for EDU and, if feasible, a callback phone number for EDU.
EDU will be activated in the following circumstances:
When in the course of a search, pursuant to a bomb threat, a suspicious object is discovered and there is any possibility that it is an explosive or incendiary device.

column3: When any explosive, explosive chemical, or ordnance is discovered abandoned, illegally possessed, or voluntarily surrendered (including ammunition .50 caliber or larger).

column2: When large quantities of illegal fireworks are discovered or seized.
When an explosive or incendiary device has detonated.
If a member intends to charge or arrest an individual with possession or manufacture of a destructive device under ORS or City Code Title 14A.60.040 Possession of Explosives or Bottle Bombs.
Provide initial response to scene where explosives or a suspected device has been discovered.
Provide initial evaluation of bomb threats and/or decision to evacuate.
Provide a safe approach and work area for EDU.
Notify the EDU sergeant of any bomb threat directed against any facility, public or private, and notify an EDU sergeant of any found suspected explosive devices.
Forward requests from outside agencies to the EDU sergeant.
Notify Detectives of any major post-blast incidents.
Render safe explosives, explosive chemicals, and hazardous devices.
Process minor post-blast scenes in conjunction with fire investigators.
Process major post-blast scenes in conjunction with Detectives (Arson).
The authority to decide how or if a bomb, hazardous device or explosive is to be rendered safe rests solely with the EDU technician.

column3: Coordinate and assign EDU and Metropolitan Explosive Disposal Unit (MEDU) members to calls for EDU services.

column2: Coordinate follow-up investigations with the Arson detective.
Obtain permission from the Operations Branch chief for operation outside of the MEDU jurisdiction or 50 miles from Central Precinct.
Advise the Operations Branch chief and the precinct commander of the occurrence of any event of significance, and any event that indicates terrorist activity.

column3: Provide follow-up investigations, and evidence control in major post-blast investigations.

column1:
EDU members not regularly assigned to the Tactical Operations Division (TOD) will be assigned to TOD while responding to calls for service involving explosives, bombs, hazardous devices, explosive chemicals, and training. Likewise, members of the MEDU will be assigned to TOD for the duration of the call or training.

0700 - Emergencies / Disturbances,Emergencies / Disturbances,529199,0710.00 Dignitary Protection,ARB-PPB-0710.00,0710.00,2,,2015-07-23 19:59:58 UTC,2015-05-04 18:57:00 UTC,A,,"

710.00

The Bureau will assist the Secret Service with any visit of a federally designated protectee. Additionally, the Bureau will provide security and protection to other individuals when directed to do so by the Chief of Police or his/her designee.
The following procedures will be employed in order to provide security for Secret Service protectees when visiting the City:

column2: Upon notification from the Secret Service, the Operations Branch chief will designate a captain as the overall coordinator and incident commander. However, if the visitor is to be the President of the United States the incident supervisor will be the Operations Branch chief.

column3: The assigned supervisor will prepare an operations order establishing the assignments for the Bureau. The order will be modified by addenda from assisting RU&rsquo
column4: s. The operations order will contain the following:

column2: During the visit, the incident supervisor, or his/her designee, will travel in any motorcade and remain on-site during all appearances.
The incident supervisor will immediately notify other units within the Bureau of the pending visit. At a minimum, the following will be notified:
All Operations Branch RU Commanders (including Reserves).

column1: 10. The Secret Service will normally notify the following as part of their procedure: Multnomah County Sheriff&rsquo
column2: s Office, Oregon State Police, Fire Bureau and Portland Traffic Engineer.

As visitation sites and hotel accommodations are identified by the Secret Service, the precinct responsible for the geographical area will be assigned site responsibility. Each site will have a sergeant assigned to the Secret Service who will have responsibility to coordinate with the motorcade and the Secret Service in order to provide the necessary support. The primary or other identified sergeant will be at the site during the visit. Any major site with the President of the United States as the dignitary will require a lieutenant as the site supervisor.

column3: All Operations Branch RUs will identify a reserve force of members with a supervisor to assist in the event that they may be needed.

column2: BOEC will be requested to provide a radio net and a dispatcher. During the actual movements of the dignitary, a member who is familiar with the operations order will be present at BOEC. The Secret Service will also be requested to staff that location with an agent who is familiar with their operations.
The Mounted Patrol will be made available and may be staged in an area so as to be available for crowd control.

column4: Forensics will be available to photograph demonstrations in order to record criminal activity.
The Detective Division Mass Arrest Team will be placed on standby. The Detective Division will also staff the command post during overnight visits.

column2: The Secret Service will establish a command post prior to the arrival of the dignitary. The command post will be staffed 24 hours a day by a sworn member when the protectee is in the Portland metropolitan area. The command post communication equipment will be tested ahead of the visit. If the need arises, the Bureau of Electronic Services will be asked to assist in order to have reliable communications with the command post.

column3: During any visit, radio earphones will be provided to members involved in a demonstration.

column1:
The providing of security for other individuals by the Bureau will be determined by the Chief of Police. The Chief of Police will designate an incident supervisor who will determine the appropriate course of action based on the requirements of the event.
