column2: A hand-held aerosol spray containing organic capsaicin oils derived from pepper plants, which affects individuals for several minutes, designed to impair vision and breathing. &nbsp
Projectiles, along with their fuses and primers, which can be fired from a firearm.&nbsp
A Bureau approved and issued carbine rifle.&nbsp
An authorized instrument designed for blocking, jabbing, striking, or to apply control holds while engaged in a police action. &nbsp
column3: Also known as an impact weapon not intended or likely to cause death of a subject.&nbsp

column2: A sworn member who has successfully completed armorer training in a weapons system currently used by Bureau personnel, and is designated as an approved armorer by the Training Division.&nbsp

A sworn member who has successfully completed a Bureau or, when the Bureau does not have a certification process, an accredited instructor school in a weapons system and is currently designated as a weapons system instructor by the Training Division.&nbsp
column3: Certified instructors may qualify members in any weapon system during a qualification range period
column4: however, only certified instructors of a specific weapon system are authorized to instruct members who are conditionally qualified in that specific weapon system.&nbsp

column2: A weapon, including Tasers, designed primarily to discharge electrical charges into a subject that will cause involuntary muscle contractions and overrides the subject&rsquo
A weapon, by whatever name known, which is designed to expel a projectile by the action of powder.&nbsp
Bureau-issued munitions that are deployed by less lethal certified officers and are fired from a launcher.&nbsp
column3: Impact munitions are not intended to produce deadly effects, but just as with other impact weapons, they can cause serious injury or death. &nbsp
column4: Although this munition is designed to be less lethal, it is not to be considered non-lethal.&nbsp

column2: A Bureau-issued weapon system capable of delivering 40mm munitions.&nbsp
column3: Bureau issued launchers designated as less lethal launchers will be conspicuously marked.&nbsp

column2: A Bureau-approved firearm (Glock 17, 19, 26) carried on duty.&nbsp
A Bureau-approved firearm other than the primary firearm that is carried in a concealed manner as a backup firearm.&nbsp
>This policy governs the authorization, safe management, secure storage, inspection, maintenance, issuance, and forfeiture of Bureau-approved weapons.&nbsp
>Members are required to exercise due caution at all times while loading, unloading, and transporting firearms.&nbsp
column3: Safety is paramount, and PPB shall hold its members to the strictest of standards regarding firearms safety.&nbsp

column2: >Directive 1010.00, Use of Force, governs the use of all Bureau-issued weapons and any other weapon used in the exercise of police powers.&nbsp
>Members in probationary status and members who are in a non-qualified status &nbsp
column3: are required to successfully complete firearm training and qualify with duty firearms and other service firearms before they are permitted to carry and use firearms.&nbsp

column2: >1.1. Vehicle storage of primary and secondary firearms, shotguns, AR-15s, and less lethal launchers.
>1.1.1. Other than while parked in the sallyport at any law enforcement facility&nbsp
column3: and lodging a prisoner, any firearms issued by the Bureau or personally owned shall not be left in any City vehicle without securing the weapon with one of the following Bureau-approved security devices: &nbsp
column4: 1) locked firearm storage box secured to the vehicle
column5: 2) chain attached to the trunk of the vehicle specifically made for securing firearms
column6: 3) secondary trunk lock approved by the Bureau Fleet Manager
column9: Simply locking the firearm in the trunk of a City vehicle without a secondary lock is prohibited.

column2: >1.1.2. When a weapon is secured in a vehicle, members shall lock their vehicles when the vehicle is left unattended. &nbsp
column3: If a member is unable to lock the vehicle under exigent circumstances, members shall make reasonable efforts to have the vehicle locked as quickly as possible.

column2: >1.1.3. If a vehicle has a weapon secured inside but is towed, parked in a service garage, or absent duty need, is left unattended for an unreasonable period of time, members shall immediately notify an on-duty supervisor, who shall ensure that the weapon is returned to the precinct armory.
>1.1.4. If electrical or mechanical failure renders the vehicle&rsquo
column3: s weapon mounting lock inoperable, the immediate supervisor shall ensure that the vehicle is placed in the most secure facility available at the precinct and the member shall notify a morning relief supervisor in writing of the need to remove the weapon.

column2: >1.1.5. The shotgun and less lethal launcher shall be secured with an approved security device in the vehicle after ensuring the action is closed on an empty chamber, safety on, if applicable.

>1.1.6. The AR-15 shall be secured with an approved security device in the vehicle after ensuring that the weapon is in the carry condition (bolt forward on an empty chamber, loaded magazine in the magazine well and the selector in the safe position).&nbsp
>1.2. Members operating in a patrol capacity shall not carry weapons on their external vests, except the following:
>1.2.1. A conducted electrical weapon (CEW) when carried in a retention holster and in a location authorized by the Training Division.&nbsp
>1.3. A member shall not carry a firearm if they are impaired by intoxicants to a noticeable or perceptible degree.&nbsp
>1.4. Members shall not unnecessarily brandish any firearm.&nbsp
>1.5. Members shall not store any firearm on Bureau premises, except where the place of storage is locked.&nbsp
>1.6. Members shall follow the rules and regulations of correctional facilities regarding carrying and storing of firearms.&nbsp
>1.7. Members shall exercise due care in securing and storing their weapons while off duty to prevent unauthorized access.&nbsp
>2.1. All sworn members shall carry one Bureau-authorized primary firearm, whether in uniform or in plain-clothes assignments.
>2.1.1. While in uniform, members are authorized to carry:
>2.1.2. While in a plain-clothes assignment, members are authorized to carry:
>2.1.3. All Glock firearms carried on duty shall be black in color.
>2.1.4. The Responsibility Unit (RU) Manager may grant an exception to this firearm requirement based on investigative needs (e.g., undercover).
>2.1.5. Firearms shall be loaded and unloaded in the designated safe areas within each precinct or division as prescribed by the Training Division.&nbsp
>2.2. All sworn members in a uniform assignment shall use the standard Bureau-issued holster specified by the Training Division while on duty.
>2.2.1. Members can submit a written request to use a personal holster to the Chief of Police through channels.&nbsp
column3: If a waiver is granted, the requesting member is responsible for the purchase, repair, maintenance, and replacement of the non-issued holster.&nbsp
column5: s RU Manager shall notify the Training Division of the waiver.&nbsp

column2: >2.3.1.1. Primary duty firearms (Glock firearms) shall be issued to all newly-appointed sworn members. &nbsp

>2.3.1.1.1. Members may request an authorization letter from the Training Division to purchase a firearm for duty use from an outside vendor. The letter shall comply with all state and federal requirements.
>2.3.1.2. Sworn peace officers who serve as Portland Fire Bureau Arson Investigators may be issued a primary duty firearm upon request.&nbsp
column3: All Bureau weapons qualifications requirements must be satisfied prior to issuance.

column2: >2.3.2.1. Only certified armorers and certified firearms instructors shall modify or perform repairs on Glocks carried on duty.
>2.3.2.2. All on-duty firearms shall have the Glock-recognized standard trigger pull weight of 5.5 pounds.&nbsp
column3: PPB prohibits modification of trigger pull, weight above or below this standard.

column2: >2.3.2.3. Non-factory sights, such as high visibility or night-sights, are authorized at the member&rsquo
column3: s expense and must be installed by a certified instructor or certified armorer.&nbsp
column4: The member shall qualify with the non-factory sights prior to carrying the firearm on duty.&nbsp
column5: Lasers and red dot sights (e.g., GLOCK MOS) are not authorized.

column2: >2.3.2.4. Slip-on or adhesive-type grips that are of a non-permanent nature are authorized at the member&rsquo
>2.3.2.5. Members may have the following Glock factory parts installed by a certified firearms instructor or certified armorer: &nbsp
column3: extended slide stop lever, extended magazine release, and a +2 magazine floor plate.

column2: >2.3.2.6. The slide, frame, or internal parts of the firearm shall not be modified in any way, except in the course of repair by a certified firearms instructor or certified armorer.
>2.3.2.7. Only Glock factory parts shall be used in the firearm, except as outlined in 2.3.2.3.&nbsp
>2.4.1. Within the parameters of this policy, members may choose to carry one secondary firearm, but are not required to do so.
>2.4.1.1. A member may request to carry more than one secondary firearm. &nbsp
column3: All requests to carry additional secondary firearms must be authorized by the Training Division Captain.

column2: >2.4.2. Prior to carrying a secondary firearm, members are required to receive approval to carry the secondary firearm from the Training Division Captain and they must qualify with the secondary firearm.

column3: At the time of the initial qualification, the certified instructor (CI) or designee shall document the serial number of the secondary firearm and qualification type in the Bureau&rsquo

column2: >2.4.2.2. The CI or designee shall verify the serial number of the secondary firearm on an ongoing basis at the time of each subsequent qualification.
>2.4.3. Members shall notify their command-level supervisors upon qualification or disqualification of any secondary firearm they usually carry.&nbsp
column3: Upon reassignment, members shall notify their command-level supervisor of the secondary firearm they usually carry.

column2: >2.4.4. No firearm shall be carried on duty that has not been inspected by a Training Division CI or certified armorer (CA) for that class of firearm. <em>&nbsp
column3: Members must also qualify on the firearm in accordance with Directive 1021.00, Weapons Qualifications, prior to carrying it on duty.

column2: >2.4.5. The firearm must be a double action revolver or a semi-automatic pistol. Additionally, the revolver or pistol must have a minimum capacity of at least five rounds. &nbsp
column3: The revolver or pistol shall be a .38 caliber, .380 acp caliber, or 9mm parabellum.

column2: >2.4.6. Secondary firearms shall be carried in a holster and in a concealed manner.
>2.4.7. No modification shall be made to any secondary firearm unless approved and inspected by a certified instructor.
>2.4.8. The approved secondary firearm should be used only when the primary sidearm is not available or is inoperable.&nbsp
>3.1. Only shotgun qualified members shall carry a Bureau-issued shotgun, except under exigent circumstances.&nbsp
>3.2. While on duty, members shall only use Bureau-issued shotguns.&nbsp

>3.3. When not in use, the shotgun shall be stored in a Bureau-approved armory in the following conditions: action open, safety on, and verified to have an empty chamber and unloaded magazine tube.&nbsp
>3.4. When checking out a shotgun from the armory or se&shy
column3: cure storage area, members shall conduct a function check to ensure the shotgun is working properly.&nbsp

column2: >3.5. At the beginning of their shifts, members shall load the magazine tube of the shotgun with only 00 buckshot ammunition or only rifled slug ammunition.&nbsp
column3: Members shall not have a combination of these two rounds loaded in the magazine tube.&nbsp
column4: Members shall load the side saddle with spare rounds of the type not loaded in the magazine tube.&nbsp
column5: If tactically feasible, members should utilize the most appropriate type of ammunition based on the totality of the circumstances.&nbsp

column2: >3.6. At the beginning and end of shift, the shotgun shall be loaded and unloaded in the designated safe areas within each precinct or division as prescribed by the Training Division.&nbsp
>3.7. A Shotgun Issue Log (Precinct/Division Equipment) shall be maintained by the precinct to record the daily issue and check-in of shotguns.&nbsp
column3: The log shall be reviewed during each shift by a supervisor.&nbsp

column2: >3.8. Non-uniformed sworn members may check out shotguns from a precinct with the permission of a precinct supervisor.&nbsp
>4.1. Only AR-15 qualified members shall carry Bureau-issued and personally assigned AR-15s, except under exigent circumstances.&nbsp
>4.2. While on duty, members shall only use Bureau-issued AR-15s.&nbsp
>4.3. When checking out their issued AR-15 from the armory or se&shy
column3: cure storage area, members shall conduct a function check to ensure the AR-15 is working properly, to include checking the attached light and sighting system.&nbsp

column2: >4.4. The AR-15 shall be loaded into the carry condition and unloaded in the designated safe areas within each precinct or division as prescribed by the Training Division.&nbsp
>4.5. When not in the carry condition, all AR-15s shall be unloaded with a yellow safety block inserted into the magazine well, the action locked open, and with the selector in the safe position.
>4.6. An AR-15 may be transported to a sworn member&rsquo
column3: s residence the night before and night after an approved training session, with approval from the RU Manager. &nbsp
column4: The AR-15 must be transported directly to and from the residence, the training site, and RU. &nbsp
column5: The AR-15 shall not, under any circumstances, be left unattended in a personal vehicle.&nbsp
column6: While in transit, members shall adhere to the vehicle storage procedures outlined in this directive. &nbsp
column7: Members shall store the AR-15 in a lockable rifle case or a lockable gun safe while at the residence.&nbsp

column2: >5.1.1. Only trained and certified members are authorized to carry a CEW. &nbsp
column3: Members shall refer to 1021.00, Weapons Qualifications, for additional guidance on certification requirements.

column2: >5.1.2. Certified members shall only carry Bureau-issued CEWs and cartridges.
>5.1.3. All members of the rank of officer and sergeant in a uniform assignment shall carry a CEW, unless waived by the overseeing Assistant Chief. &nbsp
column3: All members at the rank of Lieutenant and above may carry a CEW, if preferred.&nbsp
column4: For all other units, the carrying of a CEW remains at the discretion of the RU Manager.

column2: >5.1.4. CEWs shall be carried in a position on the member&rsquo
column3: s body such that it can be drawn with the support-hand of the member.

column2: >5.1.5. Members carrying the CEW are responsible for checking operability at the start of each shift.&nbsp
column3: Members shall also perform, at a minimum, weekly spark tests to ensure weapon functionality.&nbsp

column2: >5.1.6. Members shall exercise due care in securing and storing their CEW while off duty to prevent unauthorized access.<em>&nbsp
>5.2.1. Members shall be trained in the use of aerosol restraints prior to issuance.
>5.2.2. All members in a uniform assignment shall carry Bureau-issued aerosol restraints in a manner such that the tool is immediately available for use, if necessary.<em style=""font-size: 1.1em
>5.3. 40 mm Less Lethal Launchers and Munitions.
>5.3.1. Only members trained on and certified in Bureau-issued less lethal launchers and impact munitions are authorized to carry and use those tools in their designated capacity.
>5.3.2. While on duty, members shall only use Bureau-issued less lethal launchers and impact munitions.&nbsp

>5.3.3. Sworn members at the rank of officer and who are certified less lethal launcher operators in uniform assignments shall carry a less lethal launcher in their patrol vehicle when their primary duty is call response.
>5.3.3.1. Sworn members at the rank of sergeant and above who are certified less lethal launcher operators in uniform assignments may carry a less lethal launcher.
>5.3.4. Members shall conduct a function check to ensure the less lethal launcher is working properly, including the optic and sling prior to each shift.&nbsp
column3: In addition, members shall inspect each of the impact munitions loaded in the buttstock and leg pouches.

column2: >5.3.5. Less lethal launchers shall only be loaded with Bureau-issued impact munitions in a safe manner consistent with their training (i.e., not loaded until needed). &nbsp
column3: Certified members are required to visually and physically inspect each impact munition during loading, if feasible.

column2: >5.3.6. When not deployed, the launcher shall be secured in a vehicle with an empty chamber.

>5.3.7. The launcher shall have two impact munitions carried on the butt stock, and the member operator shall have a Training-approved carrier loaded with at least five additional rounds of 40 mm impact munitions at the beginning of their shift.
>5.3.8. Additional 40 mm impact munitions shall only be stored in a Training-approved carrier.
>5.3.9. Members who no longer wish to carry a less lethal launcher can request de-certification by routing a memorandum through channels to the Training Manager.
>5.3.10. All less lethal launchers and ammunition shall be removed from vehicles and stored in their respective Responsibility Unit&rsquo
column3: s armory when not in use or at the end of shift. &nbsp
column4: If the operator has an issued leg pouch for ammunition, it shall be stored in a locker.

column2: >5.3.11.1. Only trained and certified members are authorized to carry specialty munitions.&nbsp
column3: Members shall refer to 1021.00, Weapons Qualifications, for additional guidance on certification requirements.

column2: >5.3.11.2. Certified members shall only carry Bureau-issued specialty munitions.
>5.3.11.3. Members who are certified to carry the less lethal launcher and non-patrol specialty munitions may carry those munitions on patrol when authorized by the RU Manager.

>5.3.11.4. All certified members of the rank of officers and sergeants shall carry specialty munitions when authorized to do so in the performance of their duties as required by that specialty unit and/or at the discretion of the incident commander.
>5.3.11.5. Specialty munitions shall be stored in a safe and secure manner in the less lethal weapon&rsquo
>5.3.12. While on duty, members are responsible for securing the less lethal launcher during transport in patrol vehicles.&nbsp
>5.4.1. Members shall receive training on the PR-24 side-handled baton and the asp (straight expandable baton).&nbsp
column3: These are the only batons that are authorized for general member use.

column2: >5.4.1.1. Specialty units (e.g., RRT) shall receive training on long baton use.
>5.4.2. The PR-24 side-handled baton is issued to every sworn member, but shall only be used in specific tactical situations (e.g., riot or crowd control) as directed by an incident commander.
>5.4.3. The asp baton is issued to every sworn member. &nbsp
column3: Members who choose to carry the asp baton shall do so in a manner such that the tool is immediately available to use, if necessary.<span style=""font-size: 1.1em

column2: >6.1. The Chief may authorize, in writing, specialized weapons and ammunition for use by designated units (e.g., SERT) that are not authorized for all members.&nbsp
column3: Only members assigned to these designated units, while in that assignment, may use the special firearms authorized for that unit.&nbsp

column2: >6.2. If a member leaves a specialized unit, it is that member&rsquo
column3: s responsibility to return all specialized equipment and weapons within five working days to the unit that issued the equipment. &nbsp
column4: The supervisor must affirmatively acknowledge that all weapons and equipment are returned by the departing member. &nbsp
column5: This may be done by Bureau email copied to their respective RU Manager.&nbsp

column2: >7.1. Members shall only use Bureau-issued and authorized ammunition while on duty.&nbsp
>7.2. All magazines for the primary firearm shall be loaded to capacity.
>7.2.1. Members are required to carry at least two maga&shy
column3: zines in addition to the magazine in their primary firearm while in uniform.

column2: >7.2.2. Members are required to carry at least one magazine in addition to the magazine in their primary firearm while in a plain-clothes assignment, unless exempted by their RU Manager.
>7.3. Members shall be issued new duty ammunition at least annually.
>7.4. The Training Division shall determine which ammunition is authorized, subject to the approval of the Chief of Police.&nbsp
>8.1. The Training Division shall approve training and certification courses for every Bureau-issued or approved weapon. &nbsp
column3: Members shall refer to 1021.00, Weapons Qualifications, for additional guidelines.<strong><em>&nbsp

column2: >9.1. After discharging a weapon on duty for qualifications, training, practice, or in the official course of duty, members shall clean their weapon(s) in a manner consistent with Bureau standards prior to returning to duty unless exigent circumstances exist. &nbsp
column3: Supervisors shall ensure that members are provided an adequate opportunity to thoroughly clean their weapons(s) in a manner that is consistent with Training Division prescribed standards.

column2: >9.1.1. However, in accordance with Directive 1010.10, Deadly Force and In-Custody Death Reporting and Investigation Procedures, involved member(s) shall surrender the weapon used in a deadly force incident to Detectives or criminalists.&nbsp
>9.2. When weapons become contaminated, fouled, thoroughly wet, or dirty while on duty, members shall clean the weapon as soon as possible, or prior to the end of the shift. &nbsp
column3: The Training Division shall provide gun-cleaning equipment at the Justice Center and Training Complex ranges.&nbsp
column4: Precinct Commanders shall provide gun-cleaning equipment at the precinct.&nbsp

column2: >9.3. Firearms that are the property of the Bureau shall only be repaired by a CA for the respective weapon system, or a qualified contractor retained by the Training Division.&nbsp

>9.4. Any firearm authorized by the Bureau to be carried on-duty and found to be malfunctioning or needing service shall not be carried and shall be promptly presented to a CA or the Training Division for inspection.&nbsp
column3: Any firearm determined to be in need of service or repair during an inspection will be immediately removed from service.&nbsp
column4: If the firearm is the member&rsquo
column5: s primary duty firearm, the Training Division will issue a replacement firearm to the member until the duty firearm is rendered serviceable.&nbsp

column2: >9.5. All maintenance and repair documentation is the responsibility of the Training Division and that Division will keep on file such documentation for each firearm.&nbsp
>10.1.1. Members are responsible for maintaining individually issued weapon(s).&nbsp
column3: Members shall store their weapons in a secure manner.

column2: >10.2.1. Supervisors are responsible for monitoring issuance procedures for weapons that are not assigned on an individual basis. &nbsp
column3: Supervisors shall determine when members are required to carry additional weapons, such as the shotgun and less lethal launcher.

column2: >10.2.2. Supervisors are authorized to carry additional impact munitions.&nbsp
column3: Impact munitions shall be stored in an approved container authorized by the Training Division.

column2: >10.2.3. Supervisors are responsible for securing all weapons (shotguns, AR-15s, less lethal weapons) for members who have been injured or are unable to return their weapon(s) to the armory.&nbsp
>10.3.1. RU Managers are responsible for the security, inventory, storage, issuance, cleaning, maintenance, and auditing of weapons assigned to their RU. &nbsp
column3: Weapons include shotguns, AR-15s, and less lethal weapons (CEWs, launchers).

column2: >10.3.1.1. RU Managers shall ensure that armories established at their units meet the minimum following requirements:

>10.3.1.1.1. Maintained in accordance with Directive 60.60, Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs). SOPs will address storage protocols of weapons, the maintenance of a sign-in/sign-out log, and requirements of members prior to signing weapons in or out
>10.3.1.1.2. Managed by a certified armorer responsible for inventorying and servicing weapons
>10.3.1.1.3. Restricted entry to authorized members only
>10.3.1.1.4. Prohibit the storage of loaded weapons
>10.3.1.1.5. Ensure weapons are locked when not in use.
>10.3.2. Any firearm, less lethal launcher or CEW in need of reassignment shall be transferred to the Training Division and entered into the Police Bureau&rsquo
>10.3.3. RU Managers are responsible for ensuring that shotguns and less lethal launchers within their RU or assigned to members within their RU are inspected, at a minimum, annually.

>10.3.3.1. RU Managers shall ensure shotgun and less lethal launcher inspections include, but are not limited to, an examination of the cleanliness and proper lubrication of the weapon, a review for damage or unauthorized modifications, verification of the weapon&rsquo

>10.3.3.3. The RRT Manager, or designee, is responsible for ensuring that specialty weapons within the unit are inspected, at a minimum, annually.

<li>Aerosol Restraints: A hand-held aerosol spray containing organic capsaicin oils derived from pepper plants, which affects individuals for several minutes, designed to impair vision and breathing. Most effects dissipate within 30-40 minutes.&nbsp

column2: a Bureau-approved and issued carbine rifle.&nbsp

column1: <li>Baton: An authorized instrument designed for blocking, jabbing, striking, or to apply control holds while engaged in a police action. Also known as an impact weapon not intended or likely to cause death of a subject.&nbsp

<li>Certified Armorer (CA): A sworn member who has successfully completed armorer training in a weapons system currently used by Bureau personnel, and is designated as an approved armorer by the Training Division.&nbsp

column2: A sworn member who has successfully completed a Bureau or, when the Bureau does not have a certification process, an accredited instructor school in a weapons system and is currently designated as a weapons system instructor by the Training Division.&nbsp
column3: Certified instructors may qualify members in any weapon system during a qualification range period
column4: however, only certified instructors of a specific weapon system are authorized to instruct members who are conditionally qualified in that specific weapon system.&nbsp

column1: <li>Cold qualification: A successful attempt at shooting a passing score on the designated Bureau-approved qualification courses as prescribed by the Training Division without prior attempts or practice shots within the preceding twelve hours with that specific firearm.&nbsp

column2: A member is conditionally qualified when, after failing on the first attempt to fire their primary or secondary firearm, they achieve a passing score on the second attempt. &nbsp
column3: There is no conditionally qualified provision for the shotgun and AR-15.&nbsp

column2: A weapon, including Tasers, designed primarily to discharge electrical charges into a subject that will cause involuntary muscle contractions and overrides the subject&rsquo

column1: <li>Firearm: A weapon, by whatever name known, which is designed to expel a projectile by the action of powder.&nbsp
<li>Firearms training: Instruction received from a Bureau CI for the purpose of skill enhancement.&nbsp
column2: This may also include instructors from outside organizations who contract with the Bureau to provide approved firearms training.&nbsp
column3: The Training Division shall be responsible for the approval of non-Bureau instructors.&nbsp

column2: The ability of a member to describe and demonstrate the function and safety features on an AR-15, shotgun, and less lethal launcher.&nbsp

column1: <li>Impact Munitions: Bureau-issued munitions that are deployed by less lethal certified officers and are fired from a launcher.&nbsp
column2: Impact munitions are not intended to produce deadly effects, but just as with other impact weapons, they can cause serious injury or death. &nbsp
column3: Although this munition is designed to be less lethal, it is not to be considered non-lethal.&nbsp

column2: A Bureau-issued weapon system capable of delivering 40mm munitions.&nbsp
column3: Bureau-issued launchers designated as less lethal launchers will be conspicuously marked.&nbsp

column2: A Bureau-approved firearm other than the primary firearm that is carried in a concealed manner as a backup firearm.&nbsp

column3: >1. The Portland Police Bureau requires its sworn members to be properly trained on and proficient in the use of authorized weapons.&nbsp

>1.2.9. A member who fails to qualify on a firearm shall not be allowed to carry that firearm, either on duty or off duty, when based on their authority as a police officer until they have fired a passing score on a qualification course as prescribed by the Training Division.
>1.2.10.1. In order to be qualified to carry or use a CEW while on duty or in the exercise of police powers, each member must qualify with the CEW prior to being authorized to carry the tool.&nbsp

>2.1. Develop the qualification course for firearms, less lethal launchers, CEWs, and AR-15s with the exception of specialty units. &nbsp

>2.9. The Training Division and Professional Standards Division shall provide notice and submit for approval to the Chief of Police of any proposed changes to CEW certification rules or SOPs.<em style=""font-size: 1.1em

1100 - Uniforms / Grooming,Uniforms / Grooming,532081,1120.05 Clothing Allowance for Plainclothes Assignments,ARB-PPB-1120.05,1120.05,2,,2015-05-28 15:12:30 UTC,2015-05-28 15:10:00 UTC,A,,"

1120.05 CLOTHING ALLOWANCE FOR PLAINCLOTHES ASSIGNMENTS

Sworn members are eligible to receive an annual clothing allowance, if they are officially assigned to a function designated by the Chief of Police as a plainclothes assignment. A clothing allowance is payment dispensed annually to sworn members who are expected to routinely wear plainclothes while performing their duties.

Members authorized by the Chief of Police to receive the allowance, as specified under the current bargaining agreement and Finance Code Sec. 5.08.070, will receive the full amount if they worked a plainclothes assignment for the entire fiscal year. A member assigned less than a full fiscal year will receive a prorated amount for the number of full calendar months worked. The clothing allowance will be disbursed in August based on the number of months worked in a designated assignment during the prior fiscal year.

RU managers may authorize members in uniform assignments to work in plain-clothes as appropriate and consistent with the primary uniform mission. Members working in plainclothes under this exception are not eligible for clothing allowance and will continue to receive the equipment allowance.

1110.00, Personal Appearance Standards

column2: s appearance for the purpose of creating a design, form, figure or art.&nbsp
column3: Body art includes, but is not limited to, branding, piercing, scarification, and tattoos.&nbsp

column1: 1. This directive establishes grooming, dress code, and other general appearance standards for all Bureau members.
column2: Sworn members shall refer to the Uniform and Clothing Guide for specific guidance on uniform standards.&nbsp

column1: 2. Members will wear the appropriate clothing or uniform, be properly equipped, well-groomed and exhibit a professional appearance while performing their official duties.
column2: Professional appearance projects the image of an alert, responsive agency that takes pride in its work. Clothing and grooming will be appropriate for a business environment. &nbsp
column3: Clothing, uniforms, and equipment will be selected and authorized taking into consideration safety, versatility, durability, compatibility, appearance, and tradition. Only authorized uniforms and equipment will be worn.&nbsp
Off duty members will not wear a Bureau uniform, complete or in part, without prior consent of their RU manager. &nbsp
column4: If authorized, the entire uniform of the day will be worn. &nbsp
column5: However, the uniform may be worn to and from work if the route is direct and the member will not be involved in conducting personal business. &nbsp
column6: If worn to and from work, it is permissible to wear a civilian jacket or raincoat in lieu of the uniform coat.&nbsp

column3: Members shall keep their hair clean, neatly groomed and styled in a manner that does not interfere with their assigned duties.
Dyeing or highlighting hair is permitted, but members&rsquo
column4: hair color must be consistent with a naturally occurring color range and must be professional in appearance. &nbsp
column5: Members are prohibited from dyeing patterns or prints.

column3: Sworn member specifications while on duty.&nbsp
Sworn members shall style their hair in a manner that does not interfere with uniform headgear or any specialized equipment and will not interfere with the member&rsquo
Members shall keep all facial hair clean and neatly trimmed.
Sworn members are permitted to wear mustaches, goatees, and/or beards, with the following conditions:
Mustaches should follow the natural arch of the mouth and should not exceed the upper border of the lip or extend more than a quarter-inch horizontally beyond the corners of the mouth
Goatees should not extend more than a quarter-inch below the bottom of the chin
Beards must be well-kempt and should not extend beyond a half-inch from the face.

column4: s sideburns should not exceed a quarter-inch below the bottom of the earlobe and should be trimmed with a clean horizontal line along the base, unless attached to a beard.

column3: Members with facial hair shall have shaving equipment readily available at work should an emergency situation dictate immediate removal or trimming of facial hair (e.g., the need to don a gas mask during a crowd control event).&nbsp
The Bureau shall consider accommodations to these grooming standards on a case-by- case basis. &nbsp
column4: Such accommodations may be appropriate only in cases where the member demonstrates a religious or medical need for accommodation. &nbsp
column5: In such instances, the member shall submit a request for an accommodation through their chain of command to the Chief.&nbsp

column3: Sworn members in plainclothes or undercover assignments shall be excused from conforming to the grooming standards set forth in this directive.&nbsp
Responsibility Unit (RU) Managers shall have the discretion to establish attire guidelines for professional staff in their units.&nbsp
column4: All members shall wear professional attire that is appropriate for a work environment.&nbsp

column3: Sworn members in uniform assignments shall act in accordance with the Bureau &ldquo
column5: with regard to uniform, equipment, or other clothing requirements.&nbsp

column3: Members are permitted to wear jewelry that is professional in appearance, inoffensive and does not interfere with their assigned duties or pose a risk to the safety of others.&nbsp
Sworn member specifications while on duty.
Sworn members working in a patrol capacity/field operations in a uniform capacity shall not wear more than two rings total.
Rings should be worn in such a way so as not to interfere with the use of equipment or hinder the member&rsquo
column4: s ability to use their hands or fingers.

column2: >4.2.2. Sworn members may wear one watch, bracelet, and a necklace that is not visible.

Members may have or display body art, however, they are prohibited from displaying body art on the face or neck that cannot be easily concealed (i.e., behind the ear or the base of the neck), except for reasonable cosmetic or medical purposes.

1200 - Maintenance / Vehicles / Property,Maintenance / Vehicles / Property,532088,"1245.00 Vehicles, Off-Duty Use by Authorized Members",ARB-PPB-1245.00,1245.00,2,,2015-05-28 15:38:54 UTC,2015-05-28 15:36:00 UTC,A,,"

1245.00 VEHICLES, OFF-DUTY USE BY AUTHORIZED MEMBERS
• City of Portland Administrative Procedures Manual, No. 1425

The Portland Police Bureau prohibits the personal use of city owned vehicles. Personal, recreational, or vacation use is prohibited. However, a minimal amount of personal use of the vehicle incident to work, or as a result of being subject to call-back, is allowable. Limited exceptions are granted only as outlined in this policy.
Authorized member: A member who is authorized by the Chief of Police to drive a city owned vehicle in accordance with the criteria established in this directive.
Immediate response: Members with the responsibility to respond to an emergency occurrence, when needed, based on his/her assignment.
Off duty: The status of a member when he/she is free from specified assigned duties and not on a pay status.
Police related activities: Any functions attended by a member in an official capacity or as a part of normal duties.

column2: A marked city vehicle that Bureau policy requires to be used for commuting. No other personal use of a marked vehicle is authorized.

An unmarked city vehicle that Bureau policy authorizes personal use for so long as it is pursuant to law enforcement functions. Using an unmarked vehicle for vacation or recreation trips is not authorized.

column1: Vehicle rental: A monthly vehicle rental fee paid to the City Treasurer by those members authorized by the Chief of Police to drive a city vehicle to and from work, and for other limited activities.

Authorized members may use a city owned vehicle to drive to and from work and for other police-related activities. Members who are subject to call back must remain within a 35 mile radius from their reporting unit. Members will not use an unmarked city owned vehicle for recreation or vacation trips.
Authorized members, attending functions where intoxicants are served, will not consume intoxicants to the extent that their driving capability is impaired.

A member who is off duty and subject to call back shall notify his/her supervisor if he/she has consumed any alcohol prior to his/her call back. The supervisor will evaluate the member and determine if he/she is fit for duty.
A city vehicle will not be loaned to, or driven by, family members or friends. The vehicle may only be driven by another city employee with the permission of the authorized member.

Vehicles assigned to authorized members are a part of the Bureau fleet. These vehicles are to be made available to members within his/her division of assignment when there is a shortage of vehicles and the authorized member is not using the vehicle.

Authorized members will assist each other by loaning available vehicles for emergencies, or when the lack of an available vehicle would result in a loss of members-hours and/or poor service to the public.
An authorized member will park and leave his/her city vehicle at its designated parking facility under the following conditions:

column2: When the member will not be working for five or more workdays.
When the member will not be working for two or more workdays, and
The unit has a limited number of vehicles.
The vehicle is customarily used by other members during the workday.

column1: Members should be aware that they are subject to IRS reporting requirements for their personal use of any city owned vehicle.

Non-authorized members will not use a city vehicle to drive to and from work, or for personal business. However, RU managers may authorize a non-authorized member to use a city vehicle for a limited period when:

column3: Police or family related emergencies exist which require an immediate response.

column2: Police-related activities occur before or after normal working hours.
Used for out of town trips on police business.

column3: The member is the acting branch, division, precinct or unit manager during the absence of the assigned commanding manager.

column1: Authorized members driving an unmarked city vehicle whose assignment requires the member to immediately respond to an incident on a 24 hour per day, seven days per week basis may use the vehicle for personal use so long as it is pursuant to a law enforcement function. Examples may include:

column2: Authorized members who command a branch, precinct, division or unit.

column3: Authorized members with immediate or emergency call responsibility on a 24-hour-per-day, seven-days-per-week basis and approved by the Branch chief.

column1: Authorized members granted this exception will be required to monitor either a mobile police radio, a pack set or carry a paging system when using the vehicle.
Members assigned to the Motorcycle Detail of the Traffic Division may ride their assigned motorcycles directly to and from work, and will not be charged a monthly vehicle rental fee.

1200 - Maintenance / Vehicles / Property,Maintenance / Vehicles / Property,569272,"1205.00, Pilot Programs",ARB-PPB-1205.00,1205.00,2,,2016-03-14 15:47:32 UTC,2016-03-14 15:46:00 UTC,A,,"

Directive 1205.00, Pilot Programs
<li>Pilot Program: A short-term, preliminary trial to help an organization learn how a project might work in practice.&nbsp

• The Portland Police Bureau is committed to providing its members with proper field equipment. Research and development of any item to be deployed for field evaluation will be conducted through pilot programs, to ensure comprehensive vetting from concept to implementation. Potential pilot program items generally include anything a member may wear or use in the field (e.g. ballistic vest, firearms, flashlights, etc.), but excludes communications infrastructure and fleet.

2. Members may not keep, wear, carry or utilize pilot program items outside the scope of the trial, unless authorized in writing to do so by the Chief of Police or designee. Members may only wear, carry or utilize field equipment that is systematically acquired, issued, and/or approved by the Police Bureau, for official Bureau purposes, in accordance with Bureau policy and training.

column3: Any Police Bureau member may request a pilot program be conducted by routing a written memorandum and supporting documentation, through the chain of command, to the Assistant Chief of Services.

The Assistant Chief of Services will review pilot program requests together with the Training Division Manager, the Fiscal Services Division Manager, and the Information Technology Division Manager. The Assistant Chief of Services may assign the pilot program to one (1) of these three (3) Responsibility Unit Managers, who will then be responsible for implementing the pilot program based on the parameters discussed.
The Responsibility Unit Manager assigned to the pilot program will provide the Assistant Chief of Services with a written overview of the pilot program and a recommendation for next steps.

The Assistant Chief of Services will review the pilot program overview and recommendation together with the Training Division Manager, the Fiscal Services Division Manager, and the Information Technology Division Manager.

column6: If the pilot program is determined feasible, the Assistant Chief of Services will further coordinate implementation (e.g. procurement, policy, training, inspections, etc.), after consultation with the Chief of Police. The Assistant Chief of Services will inform impacted union representatives of the Police Bureau&rsquo
If the pilot program is determined impractical, the Responsibility Unit Manager will terminate the trial and retract and dispose of any items tested in accordance with established city procedure.

column1: 3. Records regarding pilot programs will be maintained in accordance with 8013-07, Special Project Records.

1221.00 Smart Phone Issuance and Usage
• Portland Police Bureau Smart Phone Sustainment Plan

• Evidentiary Information: Any written correspondence, photo, recording or other information taken, created or documented in the ordinary course of police business that either is evidence of a crime, or that is reasonably likely to lead to the discovery of further evidence of a crime, whether that information pertains to either the possible guilt or innocence of a subject. Such information should be preserved both for investigation reasons and reasons related to the resolution of any charges in the criminal justice system.

column2: This policy provides guidance to Bureau members about the issuance process for Bureau-issued smart phones, the appropriate uses of Bureau-issued smart phones, and technology prohibitions and considerations related to smart phone use.
The Bureau recognizes the technological capabilities of smart phones to document and gather information
column3: however, smart phones shall not be treated or used as body worn cameras.

column2: Any member assigned a smart phone shall carry or have available that device while on duty or off duty but in paid on call status, in a manner in which it is accessible. The RU manager may grant temporary exceptions to this for specific missions or assignments.

column3: Issuance and Replacement of Smart Phones.

A list of the work units and positions authorized to receive smart phones is located on the Intranet. Any variance from the established list requires written or email approval from the Assistant Chief of Services.&nbsp
Members will contact their designated unit phone coordinator for new and replacement phone requests.&nbsp
Designated phone coordinators from each unit will review and manage each member&rsquo
The phone coordinator will submit requests to the Management Services Division (MSD) Communications Coordinator, or designee, who is the approving authority for all phone requests.
Phone coordinators will process replacement requests in the same manner as the issuance of new phones.
The MSD Communications Coordinator will track the replacement cycle of assigned phones and notify the RU phone coordinators when members can receive a replacement.

Members will be issued iPhones, with the exception of callout units. Callout unit members have the option of using either iPhones or Android phones. (Android phones provide prolonged notification until the user confirms receipt).

column4: Members are reminded that Bureau-issued phones are City property
column5: therefore, members shall utilize a phone case that is designed to protect the phone. Members may use the phone case that is issued with the phone or they may purchase a personal phone case at their own expense.

column3: Callout unit members authorized to use Android phones include: Critical Incident Commanders, Crisis Negotiation Team, Explosive Disposal Units, and Special Emergency Reaction Team.

column4: Members assigned to callout units who choose to swap from an iPhone to an Android will work with their phone coordinator who will then arrange the transfer of data to the new phone.

column3: Members receiving a smart phone will retain the initial phone number assigned, regardless of the type of phone issued.
Members who have phones that are eligible for an upgrade or have phones that are unable to meet operational needs will contact their phone coordinator.
Members who retire or separate from the Bureau may request authorization from the Bureau&rsquo
column4: s Information Technology Division (ITD) to port the phone number assigned to their Bureau smart phone to their own personal phone account.

column3: Members will immediately notify their phone coordinator during business hours or the Bureau of Technology Services (BTS) Helpdesk at 503-823-5199, prompt 3, after-hours.
Members will work with ITD to identify the current location.

column4: When reporting a lost or stolen phone, members must communicate what kind of information was stored or handled on the phone, and specify if it contained confidential or sensitive data (e.g., Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS) information, crime scene photos, etc.).

column3: Members will notify their RU manager of the loss or theft as soon as practical but no later than 24 hours after discovering the loss.
Members will write a General Offense (GO) report to document the theft of a Bureau-issued phone.
Members will send a memo to their branch Assistant Chief, through channels, explaining the circumstances under which the phone went missing.
Members will coordinate with their phone coordinator to receive a new phone.

Members will return their smart phones to MSD upon separation before or on their last day of employment at the Bureau or on their first day of a new assignment that does not warrant a smart phone.&nbsp
Use of Internet-Based Social Media Applications (Apps) and Websites.
Members may access social media sites currently allowed on Mobile Data Computers (MDCs) and desktops
column4: however, members should refrain from accessing personal social media accounts on Bureau equipment.

column3: Members should contact ITD if they are unsure whether accessing a certain website is allowed. Unless necessary for a specific duty related function, members will not enter suspicious or questionable websites.
Apps, Settings, and Software Compliance and Prohibitions.

column4: Members are prohibited from factory resetting or modifying a Bureau-issued phone&rsquo
column5: s operating system. Members shall refer to Directive 317.40, Authorized Use of Bureau Resources, for additional guidelines.

column4: In the event the phone is reset or modified, ITD will notify the respective division manager of the incident and immediately lock and wipe the member&rsquo
column5: s phone if it is altered.

column4: Members are prohibited from disabling their smart phone&rsquo
column5: s location services (i.e., GPS), as this allows ITD to locate a member&rsquo
column6: s phone in the event that it is lost or stolen. The Mobile Device Management program that ITD utilizes continually updates the last known GPS location of a member&rsquo
column8: however, the GPS location services function does not keep or create record of these GPS updates. The GPS location services function does not permanently store or actively track a member&rsquo
column9: s smart phone GPS coordinates, nor does it create or provide GPS historical data sets.&nbsp
column10: This function shall remain inactive unless one of the circumstances under 5.1.2.1 through 5.1.2.3 occurs.

column5: s notification to ITD of a lost or stolen phone, ITD will pull the last known location reported to the Mobile Device Manager in an attempt to obtain the current location in an effort to recover the member&rsquo
column6: s lost or stolen smart phone.

column4: The Chief of Police, or a designee, may authorize ITD to pull the last known location of an individual member&rsquo
column5: s smart phone in a situation that the Chief of Police reasonably believes that a member is or may be in imminent danger of serious injury or death.

column4: In a criminal investigation, the investigating authority would be required to follow all applicable laws and rules regarding the seizure of records pertaining to a member&rsquo
column6: This data is not stored by ITD and is not accessible by members of ITD. In such an investigation, a court order will be obtained that authorizes the activation and monitoring of the GPS location services of a member&rsquo
column7: s assigned smart phone. This court order would be required to be served to the service provider of the cellular phone and would be limited by the capabilities of the service provider.

column4: Members are prohibited from using iCloud or similar cloud-based storage because it renders the Bureau out of compliance with CJIS. ITD may provide an alternative CJIS compliant option for file sharing upon appropriate request, based on work necessity.

Members are prohibited from forwarding information related to Criminal Justice Information (CJI) (e.g., calls, texts, images, recordings) to a personal phone. Members who do forward information violate Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS) regulations.
Secure communications are enabled on a member&rsquo
column5: s phone through the Virtual Private Network (VPN) or &ldquo
column7: function. While the default setting is set to &ldquo
column9: this feature may become disabled when the phone is powered off. Members must ensure mobility remains turned on each time they power their phone. Members will not intentionally turn off the mobility function. Members can search the Intranet for instructions on how to turn Mobility on by searching key words: smart phone or Mobility.

column4: Members shall not connect to public Wi-Fi because accessing public networks will turn this function off. Once mobility is disconnected, members will lose information and phone contacts synchronized with Bureau related data.
Members will only update their smart phone&rsquo
column5: s operating system when ITD sends an official notification approving an OS update. Members should contact their phone coordinator when uncertain if a received notification is legitimate.

column4: Members will install updates while in a police facility and through the Bureau&rsquo
column5: s secure Wi-Fi. The update process requires five to ten minutes and is completed once the phone initiates an automatic reboot and restart.

column4: Members are prohibited from disabling Smarsh, which is software that automatically downloads a member&rsquo

column4: ITD will be notified when members decline Smarsh functionality and will communicate the incident to the respective division manager.
Members will not eliminate any application installed automatically on phones at the time of issuance.
Members are only allowed to install apps from a pre-determined list to include certain social media apps, as approved by the Chief&rsquo
column5: s Office, ITD, and Fiscal Services. Members are strictly prohibited from installing Apple&rsquo
column8: s Google Assistant, and Android S Voice onto Bureau-issued smart phones.

column4: Members requesting additional functionality or applications for their smart phone will submit a memo through channels explaining the reason. Members will address specific solution(s) if identified, any costs related to the solution(s), and the added benefit from the expanded functionality.
The Adjutant for the Investigations Branch will intake each request and ITD will post the final disposition for each request on the &ldquo

column6: in the File/Search menu to locate the excel spreadsheet.

column4: A member requesting an app is responsible for checking the file for final disposition and should only submit a request for status to the Adjunct if the file has not been updated after one month has elapsed.
To prevent security vulnerabilities on the police network, ITD will audit all phones on an ongoing basis. Any unauthorized applications found on a phone will be removed.

column3: ITD only supports approved applications, services, and functions developed for Bureau-issued smart phones. Members using applications from external open market sources must contact these developers directly for technical assistance.
Member Considerations for Using Smart Phones.
Members should be aware that all information placed on and transactions conducted on a city-issued smart phone are subject to public records laws and rules.
Information on personal phones used to conduct City business-related functions such as calling, text messaging, and emailing may be subject to Oregon Public Records Laws
column4: all business-related information stored directly on the personal phone where the member is acting under the scope of employment may be deemed discoverable.

column3: All Bureau-issued phones can be accessed by BTS. Members should use discretion when deciding to store information on their phones.
In order to prevent loss of contact information in the event the phone is stolen, lost, or transitioned to another phone, members should save information to the Exchange server.

Members should be aware that government email accounts do not automatically synchronize with smart phones unless members update their network password on both their computer workstation and Bureau-issued smart phone.
Members shall not synchronize their Bureau-issued smart phones with personal media accounts such as iTunes, Spotify, or Facebook.
Members who are unable to log into their smart phone after repeated failed attempts at passcode entry and receive the one minute warning on the phone&rsquo
column4:
s screen should contact ITD immediately to reset their passcode. Members that need passcode reset assistance after hours should contact the Regional Justice Information Network (RegJIN) support team at
503-823-0085.

column3: Members in need of trouble-shooting and/or technical assistance with their smart phone should contact ITD. Members can also seek information through the Bureau&rsquo
In the event ITD and BTS cannot resolve an issue or the phone is determined to be faulty, members will contact their phone coordinator for a replacement phone.
All pictures and videos taken on a Bureau smart phone are official public records and shall be retained. Members shall refer to Directive 614.50, Release of Information, for additional guidelines.

Members must follow the established processes outlined in Directive 640.02, Photography and Digital Imaging, for uploading evidentiary pictures and videos from their phone to the Digital Image Management System (DIMS).

column4: Members will direct any issues and questions regarding the process to the Forensic Evidence Division&rsquo

If a member uses a phone to record images from another video recording device, the member shall ensure that the original evidentiary video footage is also obtained in accordance with normal evidence collection procedures, when practicable.

column3: Pictures, voicemail messages, voice recordings/memos, and any other media or communications stored in a phone that is deemed as evidentiary information by law enforcement or judicial entities shall be retained.

Members are responsible for ensuring that evidence is transitioned to the appropriate system for retention. If there are any questions about what information is defined as evidence, what systems are appropriate, or the method of transitioning information from the phone to the appropriate system, the Bureau member shall contact their division manager.

• SOP 1-21 Request to Provide Training and Submission of Lesson Plans
<li>SOP 5-2 Reintegration of Training for Sworn Members After an Extended Absence or an Extended Light Duty Assignment&nbsp

column3: >Annual Training Plan: A document produced by the Training Division which details all training due to be delivered in the next year. It identifies who will receive training, what course material the Training Division will present, when and where the training will occur, and the reason for the training.&nbsp
>Procedural Justice: The practice of engaging people respectfully and policing in a neutral and trustworthy manner, while giving individuals a voice during police encounters.
>Responsibility Unit (RU) Manager: The highest ranking sworn member or the civilian manager in a Responsibility Unit.
>Training Manager: The highest ranking sworn member permanently assigned to the Training Division.

column1: 1. It is the policy of Training Division to administer a comprehensive training program that will provide for the professional growth and continued development of all sworn members.
column2: The Portland Police Bureau (PPB) provides necessary and adequate training as required by law and policy mandates, and as required for member assignments and staffing levels.&nbsp
column3: In managing training programming, the Training Division plays a significant role in ensuring members possess the knowledge and skills necessary to provide a professional level of service that meets community needs and furthers the safety of members and the community.&nbsp

column1: 2. All aspects of PPB training shall reflect and instill agency expectations that officers are committed to the constitutional rights of all individuals whom they encounter, including those individuals who have or are perceived to have mental illness, and employ strategies to build community partnerships to effectively increase public trust and safety.
3. PPB is committed to training its sworn members in community policing principles and tactics that encourage the use of non-traditional policing responses when practical.
column2: This training shall be informed by input from both the community and evidence-based strategies, such as procedural justice and interpersonal communications skills.&nbsp
column3: Training shall encourage creative thinking, proactive problem-solving, community engagement, and techniques for dealing with quality-of-life concerns.&nbsp
column4: Training shall utilize community members and people with lived experience where appropriate in instruction.

column2: >1.1. The Training Division shall conduct an annual training needs assessment of the Bureau by August 1st of each year.&nbsp
column3: At a minimum, the needs assessment shall consider the following: (a) trends in hazards officers are encountering in performing their duties
column7: (e) input from members at all levels of PPB
column11: (i) the latest in law enforcement trends
column13: and (k) any changes to Oregon or federal law or PPB policy.&nbsp

column3: The Chief or designee shall review the needs assessment during the Annual Training Plan development process. &nbsp
column4: The annual needs assessment shall inform the Annual Training Plan for the coming calendar year(s).&nbsp

column3: On an annual basis, the Training Manager shall provide the Inspector with a copy of the Annual Needs Assessment for auditing purposes and revisions consistent with the Inspector&rsquo
The Annual Training Plan identifies who will receive training, what course material the Training Division will present, when and where training will occur, and the reason for the training. &nbsp
column4: The Training Manager or their designee shall develop the Annual Training Plan, which they shall review and update annually. &nbsp
column5: It is the responsibility of the entire command staff to provide input to the Training Division to inform the Annual Training Plan. &nbsp
column6: On an annual basis, the Training Manager will brief the Chief of Police or their designee on the Annual Training Plan. &nbsp
column7: The Chief of Police or their designee may adjust the Annual Training Plan as needed.&nbsp

column3: The Training Division shall employ a program of evaluation that provides for the collections, analysis, and review of data regarding the delivery and effectiveness of training for the purpose of improving future instruction, course quality, and curriculum.&nbsp
Evaluations shall measure and document student satisfaction with the training received
column4: student learning as a result of training
column5: and the extent to which members are applying the knowledge and skills acquired in training to their jobs.&nbsp

column3: Employees who analyze evaluation results shall report the results to the Training Manager or designee and shall include student evaluations of the programs and the instructor.&nbsp

column2: >3.3.1.1. Analysts shall provide weekly reports to Advanced Academy instructors and supervisors.&nbsp
column3: Evaluations, as well as academic score reports, shall be included in the weekly reports.

column2: >3.3.2.1. At the conclusion of Enhanced Crisis Intervention Team (ECIT) training, In-Service and Supervisors In-Service, analysts shall provide the daily knowledge tests to instructors and supervisors within 30 days.

column2: >4.1. The City Council established the Training Advisory Council by Ordinance on March 14, 2012. &nbsp
column3: The mission of the Training Advisory Council is to provide ongoing advice to the Chief of Police and the Training Division, in order to continuously improve training standards, practices, and outcomes through the examination of training content, delivery, tactics, policy, equipment, and facilities.&nbsp
The Training Advisory Council shall meet at least quarterly and will provide input to the Training Division as part of the annual needs assessment. &nbsp
column4: Each quarter (every three months), the Inspector shall report to the Training Advisory Council and Training Division regarding patterns and trends in officers&rsquo
column6: The Training Advisory Council and Training Division shall make written recommendations to the Chief regarding proposed changes in policy, training, and/or evaluations based on patterns and trends in officers&rsquo
column9: s Office shall assess all use of force patterns which the Training Advisory Council and/or Training Division identify and timely implement necessary remedial training to address those deficiencies.&nbsp

column2: >4.3. Training Advisory Council meetings will be open to the public unless the matter under discussion is confidential or raises public safety concerns, as determined by the Chief.&nbsp

column1: 5. Maintenance and Reporting of Training Records:

column3: The Training Manager is responsible for ensuring the maintenance of all training records.

The Training Division shall electronically track, maintain, and report records of training curricula, lesson plans, training delivered, attendance records, individual scores, and other training materials.
The Training Division shall maintain these electronic files in a central, commonly accessible, and organized file system.&nbsp

column3: Refer to Directive 1501.00, Field Training and Evaluation Program.&nbsp

In order to provide for the continued growth of newly appointed officers, the Training Division shall deliver Advanced Academy training to all probationary officers. Advanced Academy training shall be completed within the 18-month probationary period.
The Training Manager shall consider and approve or disapprove all Advanced Academy Training.&nbsp

>6.5.1.1. If newly promoted members are unable to attend initial supervisory training during the first year due to class capacity or other issues, then with DPSST's approval, they shall attend as soon as feasible thereafter not to exceed one additional year.

The scheduling of training has an impact on the day to day operations of PPB.&nbsp

column1: 8. Review and Approval of Training Materials:

column3: All training PPB provides shall conform to current policies at the time of training.&nbsp

In order to ensure consistency with current policy and training doctrine the Training Division will maintain SOP 1-21, outlining the process for reviewing and approving curriculum and other training materials.&nbsp
The Training Division shall determine the method used to deliver approved training curriculum.&nbsp
column4: Methods of delivery include, but are not limited to:

column3: Classroom training is used to deliver foundational materials that form the basis for decision making in the field.
Classroom Training can include the use of lecture, presentation, assessment, tabletop exercises, and/or group exercises.
Skills Training is used to provide members with the opportunity to practice or demonstrate &ldquo

column2: >9.1.2.2. Skills training can include practical demonstrations, physical practice, assessment, and/or simulations.

column3: Scenario based training is used to provide members with the opportunity to demonstrate their knowledge, skills, and abilities to solve problems in a safe environment.
Scenario based training shall be delivered in a safe environment using procedures approved by the Training Division.
Roll Call Videos are used to deliver brief and timely video based updates to members as part of their normal work shift or to provide members with prerequisite information prior to other training.
The Training Division will have the lead in the production of all roll call videos, but it may rely on other subject matter experts to develop specific content.
Tips and techniques are used to deliver timely printed updates to members as part of their normal work shift.
Tips and techniques may be developed by subject matter experts outside of the Training Division.
The Training Division shall review and approve all Tips and Techniques prior to final publication and distribution.
E-Learning is computer based instruction where training occurs via the Intranet.
E-Learning may be used to deliver standalone content or to provide members with prerequisite information prior to other training.
The Training Division shall have the lead in the production of all E-Learning modules, but it may rely on other subject matter experts to develop specific content.

The safety of the training environment is the responsibility of the Training Division. Certain types of training involve the use of simulated equipment and the use of such equipment requires a safety plan to ensure no dangerous or deadly weapons are present in the training environment.
The Training Division shall maintain SOP 1-21 outlining the process for the review and approval of a training safety plan. &nbsp
column4: During instruction the lead instructor or designated safety officer shall be responsible to ensure adherence to the safety plan.

column3: Members attending training, regardless of rank or position, shall follow the direction of a safety officer as they would the direction of a supervisor.

column2: >10.1.1.2. If circumstances require a change to the approved safety plan, all training will be stopped and a Training Division supervisor will be notified.

column3: The training supervisor shall review the exception(s) or deviation(s) and must approve them before training can resume.
If the training supervisor does not approve of the exception(s) or deviations(s), the training shall be canceled.
All members attending training shall be briefed on the safety plan and all members shall terminate training immediately should anything unsafe be observed in the training environment.&nbsp
The Training Division shall regularly review lesson plans and training to ensure that they conform to PPB&rsquo
column4: s policies at the time of training.&nbsp

column3: The Training Division shall not deliver or authorize training in conflict with PPB policy.&nbsp
The Training Division shall not deliver or authorize training unless there is an approved lesson plan on file.&nbsp

column4: In order to ensure consistency, instructors shall not deviate from the approved lesson plan.

column3: Training Division supervisors shall randomly audit training to ensure adherence to the lesson plan.&nbsp
In order to ensure consistency with current policy instructors shall only teach policies that have received final approval from the Chief of Police or their designee.&nbsp
The Training Division shall select officers to serve as trainers consistent with the following:
The office shall have a demonstrable record of professional conduct and suitable work performance and work history.

column2: >12.1.2. No officer with a history of using excessive force shall serve as a trainer. &nbsp
column3: A history of using excessive force shall be determined by the following criteria:
If the officer has been subject to disciplinary action based upon a use of force within the preceding three (3) years, or twice in the preceding five (5) years.

No officer may serve as a trainer if they are subject to disciplinary action based upon the use of force or mistreatment of people with mental illness within the three (3) preceding years, or twice in the preceding five (5) years.

The selection of officers to serve as trainers shall, at a minimum, take into account whether a civil judgment has been rendered against the City of Portland in the last five (5) years based on the trainer-candidate&rsquo
The Training Division shall maintain SOP 1-19 which outlines additional trainer selection guidelines.&nbsp
Precincts/divisions may deliver proficiency or tactical training as authorized by the Training Division .
In order to maintain training consistency throughout the Bureau, the Training Division shall review and preapprove all precinct/division training. &nbsp
column4: Specifically, the Training Division shall be responsible for the review, approval, scheduling, safety planning, recording, and reporting of precinct/division training.

column3: Precincts/divisions intending to conduct training shall submit a training plan through their RU Manager to the Training Division not less than sixty (60) days prior to the first day of the training.
When exigent circumstances exist, RU Managers may request a waiver of the (60) day requirement in writing to the Training Manager.
The Training Manager or designee shall review the training plan to ensure all training comports with current policies and training doctrine.
